It often happens that there is bleeding from an artery which has been cut at the wound site or during the incision of an abscess or cauterization of a limb and similar cases; and it becomes difficult to stop this bleeding.
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	When this happens to someone, then hurry with your hand to the opening of the artery and place your index finger over it; and press on it very hard until the flow of blood is stopped under your finger and nothing comes out from there.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then place the small olive oil cautery into the fire, and add several more large ones; blow on them until they become very hot.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take one of them, small or large, according to the wound and the place where the artery is torn, and place the cautery on that vein; then remove your finger quickly, and hold the cautery until the blood stops flowing.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	If blood spouts out when you lift your finger from the artery opening and the cautery goes out, then quickly take another cautery from those that are prepared in the fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Therefore do not stop doing this with one after another until the blood is stopped.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And be careful not to burn the nerve that is there, so as not to bring about another evil on the afflicted person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know that when blood flows from an artery, it cannot be stopped, especially if the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or by extraction if it has not been extracted already.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is pulled out, its ends contract and the blood stops flowing.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or bind it with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or place on it medicines with the property of stopping blood, and compress them with a suitable bandage.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever administers the stopping of bleeding with a thread and compression using cloth, or the application of burning objects and cauteries, should not bring them close except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	If it happens to someone and they have no doctor nor medicine present, then they should start by placing the index finger over the vein opening itself as we mentioned earlier, and applying significant pressure until blood flow is restricted from the upper part of the wound as well as the artery above it.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	The finger should not be removed from the wound but remain on top of it with cold water of intense freezing constantly until the blood becomes frozen and swollen so that it can be severed.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	During this time one should observe what is needed: either cauterization or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	End of the first part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	Book on Surgery by Albucasis, Part 2.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incision, perforation, and phlebotomy of wounds and similar injuries.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	In the first chapter we already mentioned every disease where it is appropriate to use a burning cautery with medicine and its opportunities, causes, instruments, and types of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And there I listed the topics from head to toe.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And now I will proceed with the same path in this chapter so as to alleviate the seeker's inquiry.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin it is necessary that you learn, my son, what differentiates this chapter from the terror of cauterization mentioned in the first chapter.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for this reason one must be even more cautious as the operation described in this chapter often leads to an evacuation of blood alongside which life depends when opening a vein, or performing an incision on an abscess, or a perforation intended for healing wounds, or extracting arrows and stones, and similar procedures; all of which cause trembling, fear, and among many death.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you not to stumble over that which causes hesitation, for sometimes people of various kinds with various illnesses fall to you in this art.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For among them are those who become angry when ill and for whom death is a light matter due to the severity of what they experience from their illness and the length of their suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when ill, it is out of fear that signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And among them is the one who offers his musician and enriches you with him, hoping for health, while his illness is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	Therefore, you ought not to agree with him who comes to you from among them, whose manner is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let your caution be more severe than your greed and avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume anything about him until after certain knowledge that verifies for you what the successful outcome attains.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And apply to the treatment of all your patients a prognosis and an indication that will lead suitably to their health.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	For in that is your help concerning the attainment of fame and glory, memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with his understanding, and may he not withdraw from you guidance and inspiration, for it is in his hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have indeed arranged this chapter by dividing it into sections, as has been done previously in the chapter on cauterization from the neck down to the feet, so that your search for what you wish and need out of it may be alleviated.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	The treatment of water accumulation in children's heads.
Caput I.	Chapter 1.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You know that this illness often befalls children at birth; or when the midwife grasps the child's head without care.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it happens also for an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I myself have not seen this sickness in anyone other than children; and among all those whom I saw it rushed towards death; because of that vision, therefore, it seemed to me to give up operating on them.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I myself saw among them a child whose head was filled with water, and the head swelled every day until he could not sit up because of the size of his head; and humidity increased in it until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture either accumulates between the skin and bone; or it accumulates beneath the skull above the brain.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation for this, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then you should make an incision in the middle of the head as wide as your finger; and let its length be about two fingers long until moisture flows out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a spatula.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	If therefore the moisture is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then make two such incisions there.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is beneath the bone, and its sign is that you see the cranial sutures open from every side; and water is depressed when you press it with your hand towards the inside, and it is not hidden from you: then you should make three incisions in the middle of the head, in this manner.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after the incision, extract all moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then bind the wounds with cloth and lint.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	After that, irrigate it from above with wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the binding, and treat the wound with stitches and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not stop binding the head in moderation.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	Feed the patient dry food of little moisture until the limb is strengthened and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	And another method of incision is to note where the size of the abscess appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	For sometimes it is more on the occipital bone, or on the forehead, or on the right side, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So ascend with the incision where the abscess and water collection appear to you, and split it as best you can.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, do not cut the artery, for a flow of blood may occur and the patient will die from that flux with evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	On the Incision of the Arteries which lie behind the ears.
Caput II.	Chapter 2.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When someone has catarrh which affects the eyes or chest, and is not healed by medicinal treatment, then this ultimate cure lies therein, the incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore when you wish to make an incision on them, it is necessary that the patient bow their head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then scrape the place with a rough cloth until the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then have the patient strap their neck tightly using any piece of cloth available to them.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Next, take note where the pulse in the vein is felt.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And these places where the pulse is felt are areas behind the ears that are depressed (sunken); and it is rarely not felt there except for some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark both sides with an encaustic (hot wax seal); and cut each side to a depth of two-fingerbreadths using the knife on either side, making the cuts right up to the bone; and make this incision as wide across as the breadth of your head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you wish, insert the knife beneath the artery and cut it open above with an upward stroke.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	Let the length of the incision be as wide as two fingers side by side.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the vein is cut open, the blood will come gushing out in a pulse that will leap up towards you with frequent spurts.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	But if the artery does not feel apparent to your touch, then you should measure three fingerbreadths away from the ear.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with an encaustic (hot wax seal) and make your way right up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what needs to be let out in terms of blood volume is six ounces; perhaps you will let more or less.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	The whole of it (the amount bled) should be in proportion to the strength apparent in the patient, as well as the fullness of his arteries.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Next, pay attention to the wound (the cut).
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If any bone remains exposed after the incision, then cut it away so that a hot abscess does not form; then bind the wound with linen cloths.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment until it is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	On the extraction of arteries which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter 3.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a man suffers from chronic hemicrania or acute catarrh on account of acrid humidities and heat in the regions of the temples, or an old headache, intense and similar to these, and it is treated with the methods of medical cure without avail: then we have found in these ailments the extraction of arteries from the temples or their cauterization, as we have related.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the manner of operating for their extraction is this: the patient should have his hairs shaved off where the temple shows blue.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	For it shows itself to you by its pulse, and is rarely hidden except in a few persons or extreme cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	And if it is hidden from you, then the patient should bind his head with any of his own cloths; then rub the place with a coarse cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or else fomentation of the place should be made by means of hot water until it shows itself to you in a visible manner.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take the spatula which I have just made.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape away the skin with it gently until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then thrust a hook into it and extract it upwards until you have pulled it out of the skin and made it emerge from beneath its tunics on every side.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If however the artery is slender: then wrap it with the extremity of a hook.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from it a portion according to the quantity by which its extremities are extended, and they contract, and no bleeding will occur.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and if it is not severed, the blood does not fully recede.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then draw out six ounces of blood from it until three.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If the artery is large: then you must tie it in two places with double thread, strong, of silk: or from cords of aloe, so that it does not hasten to itself putrefaction before wound healing, and bleeding occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut the excess, which is between the two ligatures.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do that at this hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you wish, cauterize it with the cautery until bone, with the knife-like cautery: until its extremities are cauterized, and will stand in place of that same work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work, unless the patient has fever, or is of hot constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cautery is among those things which help to dry up moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better assistance.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it is necessary after the removal of arteries, that the place be filled with old tallow: and decently made poultices are placed on top.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the filling is cured with dry medicines that make flesh grow, and with lint, until it is healed.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If in the meantime, while you are operating, there occurs a flow of blood from an artery, then hurry to cut it off with a cauterizer or fill the place with zegi: and squeeze your hand until the bleeding stops.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	If none of those are available to you then put your finger on the spot until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And irrigate the place with very cold water until the sharpness subsides and it tightens as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And for that which is lighter and easier to remove by way of the artery, it is done with this two-bladed cautery; let the sharpness of the two blades be like alum.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	Because if they are sharp like two knives, it hastens both coldness; and it doesn't cut the flesh quickly.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	Since there is a little roughness in them, the fire's heat is retained in them and it cuts flesh quickly; with this one, therefore, the operation is better than any other, and lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And let the space between the two blades be the thickness of a finger; after you mark two spots with encaustic; and place both very hot until they reach the bone, and cut into the vein at two points so that what is between its ends will stretch out.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For they do not heal completely with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	On treating the incessant flow of sharp tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter Four.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When tears are continuous and their flow comes from the veins which are on the exterior of the skull above the head; and you don't apply any medical cure or medicine to them, and you see that the patient's face is already red, and he feels crawling in his forehead, like the crawling of ants: and his eyes are strained, wet so much that their lashes are already corroded with corrosion; and his eyelids are heated from the sharpness of tears: then ancient physicians required this operation for their cure, and they named it a cure *with the Sword*.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And you should advise the patient to shave the hairs that are on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then make three equally spaced incisions on the forehead along its length; and let the length of each incision be about two fingers, and let one incision be equidistant to the length of the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length a little from the movement of the temples, and the third on the other side: and beware of cutting the arteries that are on both sides; and stretch your hand away from the joining of the two jaws, and let all the space of the incision be as long as three joined fingers; and have ready for you a piece of sponge, or many dry pieces of cloth, with which you will dry the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a spatula of two sharp ends, whose following shape is as follows:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the first incision which is on the side of the temple, to the second incision; and scrape with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, together with the sinew that is above the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then do it again from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then extract this spatula and introduce into the first incision again another instrument called a sharp scalpel on one side, blunt and not sharp on the other side.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place its sharp side towards the flesh attached with skin, and its blunt side towards the bone; then push it until you reach the mid-fissure; and cut through all the sinews that descend from the head to the eye: except where the incision is continued up to that which appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then make it in the mid-fissure up until another fissure.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And after an equal quantity of blood runs out, press the places from clots of coagulated blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then place in every fissure old linen from cotton, and put on them compresses soaked in wine or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And see to it that no hot abscess occurs.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day dissolve the ligature, and apply a large quantity of lotion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then treat it with the ointment known as basilicon, and other things which are used to heal wounds until they are healed.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	On the treatment of acute tears and catarrh in the eyes from internal head conditions.
Caput V.	Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When someone suffers from acute, sharp, frequent catarrh and you see his eyes are tired, small, and their appearance is already weakened; and the eyelids have become ulcerated, hair falls out of them, and there is a sharp, painful headache in the depths of the head with sneezing afterwards: then take as your starting point for these symptoms that those substances and catarrh do not come but from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And this is a better cure for them.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it's best to advise the patient to shave their forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then make an incision in the forehead, one in the middle or slightly off-center and across its width; start with a fissure from the left temple to the right, making sure it reaches the bone beneath. Extend your hand out as far as the temples move when chewing until you feel the bone. Then dry all of the blood away using a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision using an old rag or linen strips.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Afterwards, bind it from above with lint; dip the lint in a mixture of wine and oil to avoid hot abscesses.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you remove the binding and see that the hot abscess has shrunk, it is necessary to rub the bone until flesh starts growing over it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Afterwards treat it with a drying regimen that makes flesh grow; such as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony and prepare from them a plaster to be applied at the birth of flesh on these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	On treating what has fallen into the ear:
Caput VI.	Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	Anything that falls into the ear is one of four types: either a mineral substance like a stone; or something similar to a stone such as iron and its filings; or it comes from plants, such as chickpeas and beans; or it's a fluid-like material like water, vinegar and things like them; or some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When a stone falls into the ear, or a piece of rock from those that are not added to, nor grow in the ear, expose the Ear to the sun; if you then see the stone, drop into the Ear a little of either violated oil, or sesame oil.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then perform its extraction, and make him sneeze with the medicine, and hold his nostrils shut at the approach of the sneeze, after you put around the ear a piece of cloth or wool, and stretch out the ear upwards.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For indeed it often comes out with this treatment.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not come out, then perform its extraction with forceps, that is, fine tweezers; whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	Therefore if it comes out with the forceps, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	And if not, then perform its extraction with a thin blunt hook of little curvature.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If it does not come out by that, then make a brass pipe and insert the end of the pipe deep into the ear-hole, and plug what is around the pipe with softened wax mixed with oil so that there be no way for the wind but through the pipe; then draw it forth with your strong suction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For indeed it often comes out with what we have narrated.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if it does not come out that way: then take some fish-skin or from glue, that is, prepared gluten with which birds are caught, a little piece; and put it at the end of a stick after you wrap around it an untrimmed cloak; then insert it into the earhole easily, after you dry the ear of moisture.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	If it does not exit with all that we have described, then proceed to cutting before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	The method of the incision is such that you should use a lancet on the patient's head first; and draw out blood according to the measure of his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the patient sit between your hands, and turn his ear upwards, and find a small incision in the root of his ear near its fat at that depressed spot; and let the incision be of lunar shape until you reach the bone; then remove it with what is possible for you from among your instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then suture the incision with your needle swiftly, and take care of it until it is healed.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	If the thing that fell into his ear is one of the grains which grow and swell; then administer its extraction.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you by coming out, then take a thin, fine spatula in this shape.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with it the abscission of that kind from grains which fall into the ear, and do not do this when you think that the grain has been moistened by the vapour of the ear until you have tried many times; then draw them out with hooks or with a fine probe or with suction as we said, for its extraction will be made easier.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	In the case of water which enters the ear, the patient must use sneezing first; and then fill his ear with some old oil; and lie on that ear in which is the water.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If it therefore comes out by that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not, then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, thin and soft, and heat them with fire for a while; and let the patient introduce one of these into their ear hole: and let him leap upon his foot on that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore he will not stop doing that with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And now water comes out like this, you will take a piece of papyrus or reed and introduce one end into the ear; light the other end with fire until most of it is burnt.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then repeat with another reed and do this many times until all the water comes out; and extract it with a tube as previously mentioned for stones.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	But for the extraction of an animal that has entered it, if it is a small body like a flea or similar, take care as I said in the division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a large body which can be felt; then apply forceps and hooks to its extraction; and this procedure is easier than all those for things lodged inside the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But for the extraction of worms generated inside the ear, when you treat it with what we have said before in the division and in the chapter on distillations; if your treatment does not help then you must look at the patient's ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	So if you see anything there of the worms, then extract it with forceps or fine hooks.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if nothing is seen there; then take a tube with this form, narrow at the bottom and wide on top; introduce its thin end into the ear as far as it can go; then suck hard upon it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	Do this many times until all the worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	If they do not obey you at the end, then apply oil around the pipe with leather, as I said on page 32.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	If they do not leave with what we have said, then administer the distillations that the ancients already experienced in worm killing: and you will find it in the treatise of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And let your pouring be such that you pour the oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see, make it from silver or bronze, narrow at the bottom with a small hole, wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Therefore, let it be so that the driver which is in the cavity of the pipe, is off-centre and made from bronze.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you wish, take a stick and wrap some cotton around one end with an appropriate number of turns; then pour oil or juice or any medicine from these into the pipe, and let it be inserted into the ear; then insert the stick with the wrapped cotton on top and squeeze it with your hand using moderate pressure until the oil is driven into the cavity of the ear, and the patient feels it inside; and whatever you put in the ear, let it already have been heated by fire for a short time: and beware that what is distilled into this should not be very cold: for medicines cannot tolerate such things.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	On the treatment of blockage in an auricular prosthesis.
Caput VII.	Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	Sometimes children emerge from the abdomen of their mothers unperforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And now it also happens to some men that wax builds up in the ear canal due to injury or flesh growing there.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	This wax buildup sometimes occurs deep inside the ear canal, where it cannot be seen; and at other times it happens closer to the outside of the ear, where it can indeed be seen.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which occurs deep inside the ear and cannot be seen is often difficult to heal in many cases.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And for that wax which can be seen, you should place the patient's ear in the sun and look into it; then, if you see the visible wax, open it up with a thin spatula, whose shape is as follows, with its end having a small width, of which one part is sharp: and let the rest of the spatula have two gentle sides: so that it does not harm the ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	So if the wax is caused by flesh growing inside the ear canal: then hold it with a thin hook and cut it out easily until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	But if the wax is deep inside the ear then take a thin, gentle rod and warm it slightly over a fire; next put it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If you feel wax with that rod which the patient has trouble hearing, try opening it up gently; and be careful not to injure the ear's nerve.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Next put into the ear some linen rolled up in Egyptian ointment according to the size of the opening; do this for a few days until you are sure the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take some linen and soak it in rose water; then sprinkle on it some powdered frankincense, and use this.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	If you see the ear has already formed an abscess: then you must remove the pus and allow it to remain with another linen cloth that you wrap in a poultice made with rose oil until the abscess becomes warm; afterwards treat it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If there is bleeding, then immerse a sponge or cloth in cold water and place it on the ear; use the rest of the treatment that stops bleeding as mentioned earlier in the chapter on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Regarding the treatment for inflammation of the eyelids.
Caput VIII.	Chapter 8.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	These inflammations of the eyelids that occur on the eye sometimes are wet, and sometimes they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore it is necessary that you hold them with forceps or with a hook, and cut them out with a small spatula from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then put on the affected areas some crushed egg white.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If there is bleeding from them, then cauterize them with a thin lens-shaped cautery tool.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterizing after cutting is better.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For they often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots get burnt, and they do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	Regarding the treatment for styes on the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	Chapter 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	It often happens in the eyelids that there is something like a sty in its strength and hardness; because of this it is called a stye, which is a collection of thick humours on either eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	The operation for these patients is as follows: you must consider it then, if there is a progressing granuloma that appears on the eyelid and moves to any area, and its condition is easy to treat.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Therefore find over it an incision of appropriate width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then scrape away the tissue on all sides with ease until it emerges.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Next lift it up using a hook, then cut it away.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	However if you cannot cut it away unless after you have made an incision into the eyelid itself, then this will harm the patient in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	If however the incision is large then stitch it together with sutures and treat until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	For the ointment restores it and causes it to flesh over.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the granuloma declines towards the inner surface of the ear then turn the eyelid inside out and lift up the granuloma with a hook; although you will need an incision, press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If however the eyelid is lengthened by incision then this will not harm it at all.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after this granuloma incision with salt water and treat the site of the flesh-over until the patient is healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	On treating swelling of the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	Axirnath is a build-up of fat beneath the skin of the upper eyelid which most often occurs in children; it burdens their eyes and brings cataracts upon them in the morning when they cannot look at sunlight due to how tears rush into their eyes, for this reason you see them always leaning over on their faces and sleeping upon those, and there are wet eyelids under their eyebrows that have been covered by swelling. The Axirnath prominence is apparent to the eye; when you press the site with your fingers you feel axirnath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	The method for this operation is to have the patient place their head on your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a linen cloth and prepare it with lint; make from this lint a circle according to the size that fits around 'Axinam' on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then place it on top and press with your fingers from all sides so that 'Axinam' gathers at the center of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find at the center of that moisture with a pointed spatula any cracks across its width; do not let the crack be larger than what is made during phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should cut the skin entirely until you reach 'Axinam', as in many instances 'Axinam' proceeds from a crack according to the form of a piece of white fat.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Extract it therefore with a cloth which you have inserted between your fingers towards the exterior; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it is dispersed: be careful not to add anything into the crack such that you do not reach the eye with the pointed spatula and injure it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If however 'Axinam' does not appear to you at the start of the crack, you should add a little with care until 'Axinam' proceeds.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then extract it as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then soak the cloths in vinegar and water, place them on the spot, and bind it with compresses.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	There are those among men who rub salt and place it on the hollow of the crack so that what remains of that moisture may liquify.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If however there is a warm abscess in that place, then treat it with soothing poultices until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	On the ways of eye droop, that is, when the eyelid softens around the eye, causing it to sag as it shouldn't.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When additional hairs grow on the eyelids beyond the normal course of hair growth and turn white: these are harmful to the eye and can cause conditions such as persistent tears, eyelid softening, and whiteness until the eye is destroyed.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	Eye droop is treated in four ways.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or by cauterization with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with sharp medicine, as mentioned earlier in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or eye droop is treated by incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with tubes, as I will explain.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	You should place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it turns easily, that's good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	If not, insert the needle into it with the thread attached from the lower part of the eyelid and make the needle penetrate upwards with the thread, near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid where the hairs grow: then draw the thread upwards on the eyelid and turn it back with a rod.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find on the inner part of the eyelid beneath the hairs with a spatula inserted from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then extract the thread and place a small piece of cotton or cloth beneath the eyelid; then mark over the eyelid with cauterization in the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it is necessary that the shape be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid: for it varies greatly among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	For there are those who require that an extensive portion of the eyelid be cut away according to the size that is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then with the spatula find over the two lines that you have marked and begin from the greater tear duct to the lesser tear duct, and let there be one incision close to the natural hairs like the thickness of a needle.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then introduce a hook into one of two corners of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape it all away.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then bring together the two lips with a suture of fine thread and needle: wipe away any blood and make adhere what remains of the threads above the eyebrows with some sticky substances if you wish to do so; but if not, pay it no mind.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then leave the suture and threads for three or four days; afterwards take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, leave the wound without suture and care for it with something that dries and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is elevated at the wound's seal and its bringing together; but it will be better still.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	The ancients taught this method of healing.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is concern for the patient, and it comes from good work, and there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	Another method is also described by Albucasis: it involves making a mark on the eyelid in the shape of a myrtle leaf, as we have explained.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then lift the eyelid with three separate or combined hooks according to this shape that follows, then cut away what is superfluous with small scissors following this shape, with an even cut.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	If you cannot hold the hook and it does not fit evenly: take a needle with thread on it and insert it in the middle of the shape; then insert another thread near the larger lachrymal, and a second thread near the smaller lachrymal; and gather together the threads between your fingers with an even pull.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then raise your hand evenly; and lift the skin over where the boil is marked, as we have explained.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with stitches; and look after it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	If a boil occurs at your incision or your wound: treat the boil with caustic substances and similar things, from soothing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And sometimes it happens that the eyelid turns its hairs inwards.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary to use what we have said about the incision; but stitching is more artificial for both.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	On Albucasis' treatment with reeds.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	And so, turn over the eyelid and split open the inner incision as I have described.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then you will take two reeds or thin sticks and make them into canes of a length equal to that of the eyelid, their width being narrower than a spathe. And already have made incisions at both ends in which you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then bring together each one carefully over what is left of the eyelid and tightly bind both canes on either side with a tight strapping; leave this for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	The skin will die off, shrivel up, and rot away until it falls by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	If this is delayed then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until the wound heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	As soon as this has healed up, lift the eyelid; and the hairs will not scratch it.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the shape of the two canes which you will make according to this figure as regards length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	Regarding lifting out stinging hairs from the eye with a needle.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The procedure for this is to take a fine needle and put into it a thread of the thinnest silk and softest.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then bring together its ends and fasten each with a small knot; the length of these threads should be one palm's width.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then add beneath it another fine thread of short length and knot its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	The invalid should then place his head on your lap and be close to the sun so that the operation is revealed; because it is a subtle or minor operation.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then introduce the needle with a thread into the root of the eyelid and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you draw out from above a natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the hair up above the thread and introduce into the thread that hair, or if there are two or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with it until the hair comes out with the thread from the eyelid along with a natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	But if the thread is drawn and not the hair with it, draw the thread downwards with the thread that you put on it until the thread comes out through the upper opening; look at it with your eyes: then pull both thread and hair and close the eye. Leave it closed for two or three days until the hair attaches to its place and flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short then either attach a longer one of the natural hairs and raise it with that or leave it until it grows long and then pull it out.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the cure of an abscess that happens on the upper eyelid:
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When an abscess of this kind happens to the eye it is called a hare-lip.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	This type of abscess may be either congenital or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	The accidental kind comes about due to the healing of a wound or incision or burn or something similar.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the method of operating is such that you split that consolidation and separate its lips, and place between them a lint dressing, then bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And you must not use things that dry out and constrict in its treatment; for if you do that, the Alxatrati returns worse than it was before. Rather, use things that soften, such as fenugreek: and poultice with water in which althea has been cooked, flax seed: and diakoudion ointment, liquefied with one of the oils: and wrap with this lint, and treat with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your aim should be to try by every means that it does not consolidate again in the way it was at first.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation we have described is nothing other than a correction of the Alxatrati, so that it does not return to the shape of the place exactly as it was.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	§ On the treatment of Alxatrati which occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a wrinkling or contraction upwards to the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which occurs below is what is truly called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	And the accidental type happens from a wound, or a tear, or a cauterisation, and things like them.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And the method of operating on it is to take a needle with double thread and dip it into flesh, and make it go through from left lacrimal to right lacrimal until the thread comes out at both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then stretch the flesh upwards with a needle, and cut it with a spatula that is half an inch wide.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns as it should, that is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a rod and place it in the crack, and turn the eyelid with it: and make two incisions on the inner side of the eyelid, and let the ends of the two incisions be from the two corners of the incision until they meet and form an angle: so that when they are joined together this shape is made, and it is the Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then remove that flesh by the amount which is its sharp edge below, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then join the separated parts: or sew it together with woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with what we have said about softening medicines, and with linen cloths until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if any aloes happen to fall out of the crack or stitches, or by cauterization: then you must make a flat incision underneath the eyelashes of the eyelid, also according as was done before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate between the two lips with linen cloth, as we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the summary of the treatment for aloes when it is above or below, is that the procedure should be carried out according to how the aloes are prepared.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it has many variations in form: and a prudent practitioner prepares their skill with whatever way is possible to them, until they restore the shape to its natural form, or near it; and themselves being infirm, according as suits them from the operation and instruments in most situations.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Of the adhesion of the eyelid to the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	Sometimes this adhesion happens to many people, so that the upper eyelid becomes stuck to the white of the eye, and prevents it from its natural movements.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	You should therefore insert the end of a spatula under the eyelid and lift it upwards; or extend it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a thin spatula, which is not sharp like surgical spatulas, but rather slightly blunt; so that the patient is not troubled during the operation, and the spatula does not move and injure the eye with its sharpness: and let your incision be as if you were scraping off that adhesion easily, until the eyelid returns to its natural shape, and the adhesion is completely healed.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour salty water into the eye, wash it with water; or distill onto it from a sieve made for this purpose, from zinjar dissolved with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a linen cloth; and place over the eye wool soaked in egg white; and after three days use a sieve and compresses until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	On the incision of the fingernail and the prominence of the fleshy part of the tear duct.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	Know that the fingernail is of two types.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous; and it is like hard but thin wood.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, like frozen white moisture; which when it touches cold iron, or you try to grasp it with a hook, breaks off and the hook does not stick into it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	Both types do not begin unless from the greater tear duct, as it gradually advances until it covers vision, and obstructs light and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the mode of operation for its incision is: that you place the patient's head on your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open their eyes and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Next, gather the claw with a hook twice its size and extend it upwards.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take a needle and insert into it a hair from a horse, cow or goat; let the thread be strong, and double the end of the needle slightly, then fasten it in the middle of the claw; penetrate with the needle and bind the claw with thread and extend it upwards; scrape with the hair the side of the claw that follows the pupil as if you were plucking it with a hair until its very end.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut the remainder at the root of the tear duct with a thin spatula or small scissors; and leave the natural flesh of the tear duct so that there is no frequent flow of tears from its incision.
Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And sometimes the claw is extended with just a hook; or with thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scrape it gently with a thin spatula of this shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And beware that the spatula does not touch the corneal layer, lest it tear, and the pupil be perforated.
