Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But if the patient should insert it himself, this is better; because of his knowledge of the place where the object is located: and he should push downwards or pull up his hand with the instrument, all according to the amount prepared for him, until it comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	§ On the Extraction of Leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is treated with what I said earlier in the section on treatment with medications and it does not work, then look at the patient's throat in front of the sun or near the sun after you press their tongue with the instrument I described to you.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your gaze falls upon the leech, extract it with a small hook or with thin tweezers appropriately.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	But if it is not possible with these: then take a hollow tube, and insert it into the patient's throat close to their gullet; next, insert into the hollow of the tube a heated iron rod.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times; and let the patient refrain from drinking water for that whole day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a vessel full of cold water and open his mouth into it; and rinse his mouth with it, but do not swallow any of it; and move the water around every hour for another.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech immediately falls when it senses the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If however it does not come out with what we have described, then fumigate the patient with flea powder or with asa as with the instrument I described for fumigating a boil.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do that several times, since it will fall out.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is, that you take a pot, in which are living plums with fire: and let the pot be covered with a lid, on whose middle is a hole: and let the end of the instrument be fitted into it.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation, and let the patient put their mouth on the end of the tube, and close their mouth so that the fumigation does not escape, until you know that the fumigation has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall off.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall then repeat fumigation several times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the patient endure thirst, eat salts, garlic, onions, but not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is therefore necessary that it come out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which you extract the leech from the throat when it falls on it's back.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps as you see: except that it has this curve which is inserted into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to the beak of a bird called a stork, on which is a roughness like a file: when it grasps anything, it does not let go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the opening of abscesses, their incision, and treatment in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many types of abscesses, and they occur in numerous ways; I will here mention only one, which is dealt with in this book; there are different methods for opening them, and they are cut open in two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of which is an abscess that forms within itself, due to its own humors.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is because of the places where it occurs on the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since an abscess on the head is different from one that occurs at the anus; and also an abscess in fleshy areas differs from one occurring over joints; each of these has its own specific treatment method.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	Among abscesses are those which should not be opened unless after the pus inside them has matured and reached completion; while others need to be cut open when still raw, before their contents have fully developed.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	Such as abscesses that occur near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because when an abscess happens close to a joint and extends itself further until what's inside it putrefies; the surrounding ligaments or nerves of that joint may be affected too - which is the cause for that limb to contract more easily.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it's an abscess near a limb; for if you delay opening it until it matures, this will harm either the limb itself or the main body part attached to it.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or it's close to the anus - then you must open it when still immature; and do not open an abscess that is raw or incomplete, unless it's near the anus so as not to let what's inside it putrefy deep down reaching the interior of the anus, forming a fistula there, which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You should know the time of the abscess's perforation, which has matured according to its fullness; and it is at the point of pain relief, fever reduction, redness, pulsation, and sharpness of the head of the abscess: and other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And you must make the same perforation in the lower part of the abscess, and where the swelling is more prominent; and let the incision go along the length of the body, if the abscesses are in parts of hands and feet, and places of arms, ribs, nerves, arteries, and finally in all equal places where there is no curvature.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those which curve, go with the incision according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When however the abscess is in fleshy places: then it is better that you leave its incision until its digestion hardens, as we said according to fullness.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	Because if you make an incision in it beforehand, the course of its pus is prolonged, and there is much dirt and foulness, and perhaps its lips will harden, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are incised across the width of the body when necessary; or according to that which the limb requires.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And you must make a small incision in the smaller abscesses, and a large one in the larger abscesses; or multiple incisions according to the size of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are some abscesses where the skin must be scooped out; and it should be incised when it has already become like cloth, and reached its limit, which is now dead; as happens with many swellings, double ones, and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among them are those that are cut with a three-cornered incision.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And one of these is cut like the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an inguinal abscess.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And among them are those where a round incision or crescent-shaped one is administered; incisions similar to these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	But that which has no head, like soft surface abscesses, should be pierced with a shallow or flat probe only.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And when an abscess is large and has already gathered a lot of pus, and you pierce it, do not rush to extract all the pus at that moment; rather, draw out just some of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then cover the abscess until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then extract some more of the pus.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times in stages, until it discharges; especially if the patient is weak, or a pregnant woman, or a small child, or an old and feeble person: for often the vital spirit of one animal is weakened with that of another when pus escapes; and perhaps your patient will die, though you are unaware.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take great care in this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have pierced these abscesses with this probe, it is necessary that you clean the wound; take note.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore the abscess wound is small or the incision flat, then apply a lint dressing of linen, or an old cotton one.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If there is a large abscess and many perforations are present, you must then insert a licinia into each fissure until they meet one another.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut away a portion of the skin in the abscess or have hollowed it out around its circumference, then you must fill it with old cotton, or as when one dresses a wound with cloth, or scrape linen wool without moisture and press it until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it, and treat it with the appropriate ointment until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If there is a flow of blood during your operation, then apply cold water and vinegar after a cloth has been soaked in them; place it over the bleeding area several times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists, you must apply a regimen of treatment and powders that I have described in many places throughout this book and its sections.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is wintertime and the site of the abscess involves many nerves, then you must pour warm poultices mixed with wine and oil onto those areas.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is summertime and the areas are fleshy, then you must apply poultices soaked in water and oil or with wine and oil, keeping everything cool.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as I have said, you must then remove the abscess, clean it, and apply appropriate treatment until it heals.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	Thus ends the general knowledge of abscess treatment.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the path of division, I have now spoken about every type of abscess; how one should treat each in a summary fashion.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the draining of abscesses that occur on the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Abscesses occur on the skin of the head that are small and are similar to the species wens which are contained by sacks (tunics), like chicken pox itself.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many types of them.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fatty; some contain moisture like mud; and others hold moisture resembling curds and whey; and there are those similar to them; and there are hard stony ones among them.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And when draining all of them and extracting them there is no fear so long as during their drainage the artery does not offer resistance.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the procedure in draining them is that you should try it out with an instrument whose form comes after this, which is called "Intromissum", until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it holds moisture then dry it with a shallow incision lengthwise like this shape.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin the incision from the line b to the line g. So when it is drained of moisture then scrape out the cyst which contains that moisture and do not leave anything behind in it.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For often it returns if something remains from it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the cloth in Egyptian ointment if it is available; and if not then in water and salt; and fill with that your wound and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For the cloth will eat away what remained from the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the procedure with the second and third Egyptian [bandages], and if you need it, do so until you are confident that there is nothing left of the cyst; then treat the wound with ointment until it is healed.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the abscess contains a fatty nodule, then cut it open like so, with an incision shaped as a cross, and insert hooks between the lips of the incision; scrape out its contents from all sides: and attempt to remove the capsule that contained it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If an artery gives you trouble, then do what I shall describe to you next.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And do likewise for an abscess that is stony hard, by making the same kind of incision and treatment as we have described.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the operation on a stony-hard abscess is easier because there is less blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are abscesses of this sort on the head which contain no moisture whatsoever.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is to say that I once operated on an abscess in the head of a very old woman and found it as hard and solid as stone; rough and white; which could not be broken or crushed with a blow.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other kinds of abscesses occurring on the head however (apart from those that occur on children's heads and at the roots of their ears), all such incisions should be made on a superficial plane.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make an opening at the lowest point of such swellings so as to allow the purulent discharge to drain downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then treat them with whatever is appropriate for their treatment.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	The removal of goiters from the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses occur frequently on the neck, under the armpits, and in the groin area; sometimes they also appear elsewhere on the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And those that occur on the neck may be singular or multiple; they develop from each other and every goiter among them is contained within its own membrane as with lumps and abscesses of the head, as we have described.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	There are many types of goiters.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	Indeed, some of these goiters contain stones; others contain fluids; still others are malignant and do not respond to treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	For any goiter of good prognosis that you encounter—one which is close to the color of the skin, moves freely on all sides, and is not attached to the neck muscles or veins—you should remove it by making a shallow cut from top to bottom following the lines b-g; then scrape away the skin all around and stretch out the two edges with a hook or several hooks if necessary as we described for head abscesses, and gradually extract it.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And one must take care not to cut any veins or nerves.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	The knife should not be too sharp; in this way you won't hurt your hand during the operation or upset the patient and make an unnecessary cut.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If you cut a vein or artery and it prevents you from continuing the operation, then place on the wound some ground-up fig or blood-clotting powders; bind up the wound tightly, and leave the patient to rest until the swelling has gone down and the injury softens; or it may begin to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is cut off by the tincle. Return therefore to your operation until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then check with your index finger if anything remains of the small strophulus; then cut them out and clean them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	But if there is a large vein in the root of the strophulus, then you must not cut out that strophulus from its root; rather, it is necessary to tie it with double strong thread and leave it until it falls off by itself without causing harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with old cotton, which you have already soaked in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then treat it.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the entire strophulus is cut off, then you must bring together the two lips of the wound and join them immediately after seeing that there remains no excess whatsoever.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is an excess left due to the size of the strophulus, then it is necessary to pay attention to cutting its root and pulling it out; and apply the suture we described.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And as for those strophulus that contain moisture, make a shallow hole in them so that the place of its ripening appears to you; and put the hole below what follows from the body, as we said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then apply dressings with ointment and similar substances after the hole to eat away what remains of the corruption until you see that the wound is now cleansed; then treat it with an ointment for generating flesh until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the cutting of the epiglottis from an abscess occurring inside the throat:
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients called this incision 'in the epiglottis', and I have not seen anyone in our land perform it; these are the words of their writings.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	For those with synanche, the incision in the epiglottis should be avoided; it is not beneficial due to the weakness of all the veins and the lung.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those with a hot abscess in the mouth or throat, or on both tonsils when there is no illness in the trachea, an incision of the epiglottis should be made to avoid destruction caused by choking.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to make such an incision, it should be made under the three or four circles of the epiglottis with a small transverse cut between two circles; this should be an incision in the siphon and not the cartilage: this is indeed the suitable place for the incision as there is no meat on it, and the blood vessels are far away.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, they should stretch the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	They should then make an incision in the skin until they reach the trachea; avoiding any blood vessels that may be seen.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	After making the incision in the siphon as described, an indication that the trachea has been properly cut is when phlegm emerges from it, along with what was inside and a loss of voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	Leave the wound open for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the hour of danger from choking has passed, bring together the two lips of the skin wound and sew them solely without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that cause flesh to grow until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis says so.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The full explanation of this discussion which we have related is not evident until they see that one of these abscesses has already choked the patient's throat; and the patient is lifted up towards death, and wishes to be cut in order to ease his breathing: they go on to cut open the epiglottis so that the patient can breathe over the wound in a certain way, and he will be saved from death. And for this reason, they have recommended leaving the wound open until the illness has run its course - and this takes about three days or thereabouts; then therefore they recommend closing up the wound and curing it until it is healed.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And what I myself have witnessed is that one woman took a knife and put it into her throat, and cut with it a part of the trachea.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to treat her, and I found that she was moaning like the moan of a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	So I removed the knife from the wound, and found that there was only a small amount of blood coming out of the wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore I was confused because she had not cut the vein nor the windpipe, and air was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore treated the wound and cured it until it was healthy; nothing happened to the woman apart from a hoarseness of voice, and she returned home after a few days having improved her condition.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Thus I say that there is no need to fear cutting open the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the removal of a hernia in the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter Forty-Four
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess named hernia of the throat is a large one, resembling the colour of flesh, and it occurs frequently among women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is in two forms: either natural or accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, the natural one does not arise from any inherent tendency.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental kind has two types, one of which resembles fatty swellings.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other type is like an abscess that forms from arterial pulsations.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is a risk involved; and it must not be presumed that an iron instrument should be applied to it unless the hernia is small. You must test it, and investigate it with your fingers.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	So if you find it resembles a fatty swelling and no vein is attached to it, then cut into it as swellings are excised; and extract what surrounds the hernia from the sac, if there is one, or else explore the entire area.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with whatever is needed for healing until it is cured.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On excising swellings resembling fatty masses.
Caput XLV.	Chapter Forty-Five
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many types of swellings; and I have already described all their varieties earlier on. Now it is necessary to explain the distinction between a swelling and an exitura, as this causes uncertainty.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say, therefore, that when there is a departure of warmth and fever, and violent pains until the boiling of superfluities subsides, and putrefaction is complete; then indeed fevers and heat are quieted.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When there is no warmth nor fever or pain and they contain them with a wound dressing, which is their own sack, and it matches the colour of the body; and its beginning is like chickpeas, and it becomes like batecha, and larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two types; either fatty or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colours of the moisture are many, as I said in my classification.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	You should therefore, when you come to the treatment of a nodule, test it first and examine it with an instrument called an intromittere as described in the chapter that follows.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The method of examining boils and all nodules is to take this instrument and insert it into the moistest place you find within the boil; and turn your fingers with it little by little until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then extend your hand according to the measure of the size of the boil.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the intromittere and observe what comes out on its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture comes out flowing whatever its colour: then dry it with a shallow incision as I said for other boils.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if moisture does not come out on the track of the intromittere then know that it is fatty; therefore make an incision in the shape of a cross over it as I taught you: and hang it with hooks and scrape off the skin all around easily: and keep the dressing, if you can, so that you remove the whole thing healthy along with the nodule.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the cyst is ruptured during surgery and it is not possible to remove it whole, as this often happens, then remove it piece by piece until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	If even a little bit is left behind, whether small or large, the lump returns for the most part.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if it overpowers you and a small amount remains: then fill the wound with some sharp corrosive powders at the end of your procedure; bind up the wound, and place on it what sits on a warm poultice, and treat it with the rest of the cure until it is healed.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore there is a large lump, then seize its two lips, and treat it with that which promotes flesh growth.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	But if a pulsating or non-pulsating vein opposes you, then hurry and fill the place with crushed egg, and leave it bound for two or three days until the wound putrefies and the blood boil ceases; then return to cut off what remains of the lump.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Regarding instruments from outside for cutting and piercing...
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these are the shapes of Introductors, and they are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from them there is large, and from them there is medium, and from them there is small.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	They shall be made of iron fulcrums with square off-centre ends so that they hurry entry into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the shapes of Probes, that is, piercers: and one of them is called a borer; and they are of three types.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	There are large ones, medium ones, and small ones among them.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	They agree to investigate those abscesses, discharge, fistulas, and swellings due to what is between them of the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and soft like large needles with which saddles are stuffed, namely, of leather or bronze, iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And the best among them are those made of leather.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	Experience is also gained from black lead, which they agree to use to test fistulas with concave reflections so that they can be reflected gently along with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And there are again three types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because among them there are long ones, medium ones, and short ones, according to the size of the fistula's width and constriction.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of swabs, and there are many types.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because among them there are simple ones, that is, those with one curve; and they are of three types as you see, large, medium, and small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And among them there are blind swabs; and they are of three types.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And among them there are hooks with two curves and they are of three types; and among them there are hooks with three curves and they are also of three types; and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels with which nodules and abscesses are cut and scraped; and they are of three types: for among them there is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities, which are cut, are sharp, the other extremities are not sharp; and they are not placed like this unless with them a benefit is done to lessen the scarring of nodules through fear of incision into a vein or nerve: and so that the patient might be cured, and find some relief from the burning rather than finding it in the excoriation of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	I am Magda, and I am of three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of brass, and they look like a radio, with which alcohol is made; and at the broad end is hidden a pointed instrument called a Spatula Millimetre: and in it runs to the inside and outside when you want, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the spatula millimetres that are hidden between fingers at the abscess piercing; and they go unnoticed by patients; and there are three kinds, large, medium, small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The shapes of the windbags with which the flow of blood is cut; and they are three types, large, medium, small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	They are made of brass or quartz, round, slightly long as you see; and let them be thin.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And you must have these types of windbags large and small with you; so that you may cut blood swiftly in need, then when medicine is not available to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But you should not use them to cut blood in every place of the body; and only use them on fleshy areas such as the calf leg, hip, arm forearm, breast nipple, stomach, groin, and similar fleshy moist parts.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes small instruments are made from them similar to pistachio shells, according to their form; with which blood is cut off when it flows out of a place where venesection has been done, or at the incision of a vein or artery; and sometimes they are made round in this shape.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of human teats that resemble women's breasts.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the teats of some men swell up at the end of sleep (that is, when they begin to pollute in their sleep) until they resemble women's breasts: and they remain unsightly and disfigured.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Therefore, whoever is disgusted by this should cut above the teats with a lunar incision, according to this form: from line b to line g. Then scrape off all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill the wound with incarnatio medicine.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and treat it until it is healed.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the teat droops downwards and softens because of its size, as happens with women: then it should be slit on its two upper sides by two similar lunar-shaped incisions, each of which is contained with the other at the end of either side, so that a larger containing line encloses a smaller enclosed one, according to this form: from line b to line g. Afterwards scrape off the skin that is between the two lips, and remove the fat, and apply what we have said about sutures and powders, which is necessary for treatment, until it is healed.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not complete the incision because of the patient's unease or due to a flow of blood: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with subcutaneous cautery and leave it until it has burnt away all the remaining fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Treat him until he is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the perforation of an abscess which occurs under the armpit.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which occur under the armpit are of a hard type with cysts and some have fluids inside them.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Those abscesses with fluids must be opened by making a crescent shaped incision from line b to g according to this pattern. When all the pus has been drained from it, fill the wound with old oil and leave until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then remove the old oil and dress with an appropriate ointment until healed.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the type with hard lumps then make an incision on top as we mentioned before for the treatment of boils.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If the wound extends so that it discharges pus then apply a hot iron to it as we mentioned before.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the opening of an abscess which occurs next to a large artery or vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery bursts and the skin above it heals over then this frequently causes abscesses to form; likewise when a vein is injured an abscess and swelling may occur there too.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	The signs by which you can know that the abscess and swelling are next to a large artery or vein are as follows: if it is an abscess caused by an injured artery then it will be long, deep within the body; also when you press your fingers against such an abscess you feel a kind of hissing sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And what lies near the Vein is rounded on the surface of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And an incision above this abscess is a mistake, especially if it is under the armpits, groins, neck, and other parts of the body; and it is extremely dangerous.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is therefore necessary to avoid treating it with an iron instrument, and what comes out from them must also be avoided, even if they are on the extremities or head.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	For that which comes out from them as a result of an arterial hole becoming swollen, you should make an incision in the skin lengthwise.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the incision with hooks, afterwards the artery; and free it from its coverings until it is fully exposed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Next, introduce a needle under it and make the needle penetrate to the other side; then tie the artery with double thread at two places, as I have instructed you when removing two arteries from the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then lance the place between the two ligaments with a scalpel until all of the blood that is in it comes out and the abscess is drained.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply medication that promotes suppuration until the ligaments fall off; afterwards treat it with suitable ointments until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If the abscess is due to an incision into a vein, then you must hold as much of it with your hand as possible along with some skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Next introduce the needle under the place that you are holding with your hand and make it penetrate; have double thread on it so that when you withdraw it from the other side, the thread remains.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind it with a good ligament to the abscess; as I told you for binding a wound, on both sides with two ends of the thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	However, if you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then insert another needle with another thread underneath the abscess along the entire length of the needle's insertion; push and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then cut the abscess in its middle until whatever is inside comes out; then cut away the excess skin and leave what has been bound from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on it a poultice that you have soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the treatment which is done with linen cloths and ointments until it is healed.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On an abscess caused by nerve torsion.
Caput L.	Chapter 5.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	Just as an abscess occurs in arteries and veins, similarly an abscess occurs in nerves; which happens to them is due to impact or excessive exertion, and the like; and it most often occurs in them at places of ligaments, or the heel bone, and in any place where joints move; and this abscess is serious.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its colour is similar to the rest of the body, and it has multiple manifestations without pain; and when it is pressed vigorously, he feels in it a weakness like numbness.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess that accumulates deep within the body; rather, it is under the skin and moves to every side; and does not extend forward towards the front or backward toward the back.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore what occurs to them in joints should not be invaded with iron (surgery).
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps contraction may occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	Remove the skin from those on the head or face with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps and cut it off at the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then lift it with a hook and scrape it; then remove it, and join the wound with stitches; and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the removal of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Some people often have swellings in their abdomens and other parts of their bodies that are called "Fungalia", due to their resemblance to mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of which is thin, its head is large, and its lips are turned inward.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And there is one that is small among them; and there is one that grows to an extraordinary size.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have seen a man with two such swellings in his abdomen, which were more like mushrooms than other things: there was no difference between them, for they had thin roots, their lips turned inward, and they oozed moisture constantly.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So I cut them out and found that one weighed about 10 ounces, while the other was about 6. The procedure for cutting these out is to consider first whether the patient is moist-complexioned and the color of the swelling is white and its root thin; then cut it with a broad spatula and have cauteries ready in the fire nearby.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled when it is cut; therefore hasten if the blood defeats you, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see him weak, fearful and afraid of the incision with the iron, then take a lead wire properly made, and tighten it with an athirl whose mode is as we said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the lead tightening.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not stop tightening the lead every time it presses on the wound until it is cut off and falls by itself without effort.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	But if the wound is of a large root, then there is something to fear and be afraid of in its cutting; especially that which is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However it's possible to cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it doesn't return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then treat it until the wound is healed.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware lest you presume to cut a wound that is dark in colour, with little feeling and of ugly appearance; for it is indeed a cancerous abscess: and I shall come with a reminder about cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	§ On the treatment of an umbilical hernia.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	An umbilical hernia is formed from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from a hernia sac or intestine protruding through a tear above the belly, as happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	The wound should be closed either with the blood flowing from the vein or with that from the artery, according to what has been stated before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or by compression of the windiness within it.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	But if it is due to a crack in the shaft and there is an exit for pus: then it has an abscess-like appearance similar to the colour of the body; and it is soft, painless: and the location appears diverse.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the egress of the intestine, then its location is, as we have described, of a more violent diversity.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it is hidden; then it returns, and there may be a sound with it; and it increases greatly on entering the bath and with violent effort.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	But if it is due to moisture, it is soft; then when you press it with your hand, it is not hidden nor constricted and nothing is added to it.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then an abscess appears with these signs towards blackness of the skin.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	But if it is due to newly formed flesh, then the abscess is serious, large, hard and swells according to one quantity.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is due to windiness, then its touch is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the treatment of it is, as you should then consider, if the navel's prominence is due to arterial or venous blood or windiness; then you ought to be restrained from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and dread in it, as I taught you in the chapter where I said abscesses due to artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the swelling of the abdomen is due to a bowel or belly obstruction, then you should advise the patient to hold their breath and stand up straight.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark around the circumference of the abdomen with encaustic (hot wax).
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Next instruct him to lie face up between your hands on his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then encircle with a broad spatula around the abdomen, on the place that you marked with wax.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Next extend the center of the abscess upwards, using a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him tightly around the circumference with a strong thread or cord made of durable silk, and make sure to tie it off securely.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Next open up the extended center of the abscess above the binding.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you find that it has already been caught by the binding, then remove the binding and insert your index finger into it, pushing the bowel towards the interior of the abdomen; and if you find an obstruction, take it with the hook and cut away its excess.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If however you encounter an artery or vein that opposes you, then bind it tightly several times around.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your procedure.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles and thread them with two strong threads; insert the two needles into the circumference that you made around the abscess, in the form of a cross, making sure to pierce through.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Tighten the abscess at four places on top of the needles; and if you wish, remove the needles, leaving space until the swollen flesh rots away by itself; or cut it off when it is softened by putrefaction.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with whatever ointment is necessary until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If there is an umbilical hernia made of flesh or fluid, it must be treated with a concave poultice as we have explained.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood or fluid that you find inside it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then treat it with whatever hardens the area.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On treating cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken about the types of cancer and how to treat them with medicines, as well as what precautions must be taken during treatment so it doesn't turn into an ulcer, and we've also mentioned that some cancers form in the womb and we spoke about their respective treatments too.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	The ancients have said that sometimes cancer is found at a place where it can be eradicated entirely - like breast or thigh cancers and their likes among the limbs, especially if they are small in size when found.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is large and has become old, one should not get close to it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I have never been able to heal anyone of it, nor did I see someone before me who managed to do so.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	When it is located as we have described above, the treatment must be such that you precede and treat the patient for black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then bleed them if they have an obvious fullness of blood.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for treatment with whatever preparation is necessary.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw in hooks for crabs that suit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterwards hollow out the whole thing from all sides with a knife according to your inspection until nothing of its roots remain: and let blood run and don't cut it quickly but squeeze the places and wipe thick blood with your hand or whatever is possible there among instruments.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if a flow of thick blood opposes you from an incision of the artery or vein then cauterise the vein until blood is cut off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with remaining treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On the treatment of dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already spoken about the classification of dropsy types and how water gathers; and signs of every type as well as treatment with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron is only ascites type; and it does not come close to tympanic type or hyposarcous type at all for the latter is fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this tympanic type of dropsy with medicines and it did not yield to your treatment then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if the patient is already weak or has another illness besides dropsy such as a cough or diarrhoea then beware of treating them with iron since it is dangerous.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a patient with exuberant strength and no illness besides dropsy alone nor is he young or old then the method of treatment in him is that you lift up the patient standing between your hands while an assistant behind him presses his belly with their hand pushing water to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a sharp spine, in this shape.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It is of two acute parts, long, with a sharp end like the spine.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	However, it should have some gradual shortness to it, so that you do not penetrate with it during the operation all the way into the intestine and injure it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider this.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a swelling of the hydropsy caused by obstruction from within the intestines, then you should extend your cut three finger-widths below the navel to its lower end straight above the pubic bone.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	But if the hydropsy is caused by disease of the liver, then make your cut to its left three finger-widths from the navel.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the swelling is caused by disease of the spleen, then make your cut on his right side; and do not also make a cut over the side he wishes to lie upon, so that superfluities may not run into this weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce through with your instrument the whole skin.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then introduce your hand into the incision and raise it with the spine between the skin and subcutaneous layer as if you were scraping it; and let what is scraped off be about the quantity of a fingernail or thereabouts.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then scrape until you come to the spine-like structure at the place of emptiness; and this is where water collects.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it and introduce into the hole an instrument of this shape.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	It is like a small pipe; it is made of silver or brass or gold alloy, smooth and clean; at its lower end there is a small hole, while on its sides are three holes, two on one side and one on the other; and its tip is cut obliquely, as you see; at its upper end is fixed an armlet.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	When the instrument reaches the water, it immediately descends onto the instrument; therefore, remove from the water within a medium amount of time.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	If you remove [the patient] from it more than is appropriate, then perhaps the sick person dies within the hour due to a resolute animal spirit; or there occurs syncope which approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But remove [the patient] from it according to the amount of their strength, and according to what the sick person's dispositions indicate to you regarding the strength of their pulse, and their well-being.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then extract the instrument and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	This is because it is immediately retained by the skin which retains the hole that is on the sifac; of which I narrated, so that you may perforate it in that manner.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then reinsert the instrument on the second day, if you see that the sick person can tolerate it; also extract a small amount from the water.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this for several days without fear, and guard yourself against error; until nothing remains of the water except a small amount.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	But if you fear for the sick person, and let out a great deal of water; then treat it with burial in warm sand, and profuse sweating in bath and sun, and look out for thirst; and treat it with drying medicines until they are cured: and cauterize over stomach, liver, and spleen after extraction of water, as I narrated earlier.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On the treatment of infants who are born with their urinary passages unperforated.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When a child emerges from their mother's womb and their lambdoid suture is not fully formed or has an abnormal opening, or is located in the wrong place.
