Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	Know that castration is forbidden by our law; and for this reason it might be permissible for me not to recall it in my book at all; yet its recollection proves necessary in two ways.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	One of these is so that the physician may possess knowledge when asked about it; and to know its cure for one who has undergone such a thing.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	One other method is that we often require the castration of certain animals for our use as livestock, such as rams, goats, and cats, and similar among animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that castration is performed in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Either by scraping or cutting off the testicles.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by making an incision and then dividing [the testes].
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	In the procedure that is done by scraping or cutting off the testicles, the way of operating is as follows: have the animal sit in warm water until its testicles soften and relax and hang down; then rub them with your hand until they dissolve and are no longer apparent to touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	In the procedure that is done by making an incision and then dividing [the testes], you must hold the animal and press the skin of its testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tie the suspensory ligament and cut above each egg with one incision until two eggs appear; then make an incision in them after you have scraped away the tunics of both, without allowing anything to come out except for a thin film over the vas deferens.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than the one done by scraping or cutting off the testes because abrasion may leave something from the testicles so that the animal still has desire for intercourse.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound until it is healed.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	On caring for an hermaphrodite, there are two methods.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	An hermaphrodite comes from men in two ways.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them is because it appears on what follows the space or on the skin of the testicles, between the two testicles, a shape like a woman's vulva, with hair; and sometimes urine runs from what is on the skin of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	There is one type in women, and it is the woman's vulva like a man's small testicles entirely prominent to the outside; of which one is like Priapus [an ithyphallic deity], and two are like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the cure for three types [of this condition], two from men and one type from women, is: because you must cut away the added flesh until the impression of them has disappeared.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then treat it with the cure for other wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	For the second type of men from which urine comes out, that is on the skin of the testicles, there is no operation and nor is there any cure for it at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	On incising warts and raised flesh on the vulva of women.
Caput LXXI.	Chapter 71.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	A wart is perhaps added on top of the natural [part], until it becomes ugly and its appearance becomes unsightly; and sometimes it grows in some women so much that it becomes enlarged like in men and reaches up to the point of sexual intercourse.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	So you must hold the superfluity of the wart with your hand or a hook and cut it; and do not hesitate to make the incision, especially at the root that is deep down; so that heavy bleeding does not occur.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the cure for wounds until it has healed.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	Flesh that grows at the opening of the womb is flesh that develops until it fills up said space; and perhaps extends to the outside in a form resembling a tail, and for this reason some of the ancients called the disease 'tailed'.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	We should therefore cut it out like we do with warts, and treat it until it is healed.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	On the treatment of alratic ulceration, which is a woman's unpierced wound.
Caput LXXII.	Chapter 72.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	Alratic ulceration is when there is an unpierced wound on a woman or a small opening.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	Accidental alratic ulceration is due to an illness that has occurred beforehand, and it itself arises either from additional flesh born of the womb's lining or its membrane, and happens either deep within the uterus or in its sides, top, or bottom; and prevents intercourse as well as impregnation, childbirth, and perhaps even menstruation.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	Its diagnosis is made through the observation of midwives if the obstruction is apparent nearby.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	But if it's not visible, then search for it with your fingers or a rod.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	However, if the obstruction is due to a thin membrane and it's near the two lips of the vagina, then quickly rupture it.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And this is done by placing swabs over the two lips.
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place both your index fingers together; the woman should be on her back with her legs spread.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then extend the two lips with strength until the sifach is torn open and the blockage is revealed.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	After that, take wool, soak it in oil, and place it on the site; the woman should repeat this daily so that another scar does not form.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	But if the sifach is thick and dense, then it must be cut out with a spatula that is two spans wide, similar to the leaf of a myrtle tree.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	However, if the blockage is made of flesh, then lift it with hooks and cut it; have on hand medicines that will stop blood flow without stinging, such as gum arabic, dragon's blood, and oil mixed with egg white.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then insert a lead pipe of sufficient size so that the wound does not heal quickly; leave it in place for several days and apply a linen poultice before treating with other medicines until healing is complete.
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when birth defects of other flesh arise, they must be cut out in this way: for as long as the abscess is not a cancerous one (for with a cancerous abscess that is in the womb, iron must on no account be used).
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	On the treatment of haemorrhoids, athehelil, and red botches on women's vulvas.
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Haemorrhoids indeed are the opening of the veins until much blood flows out persistently.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When haemorrhoids are dried up they become athehelil; and I have already spoken of the different kinds and their symptoms in another section, and here will say which of them can be treated and which cannot.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, therefore, that haemorrhoids which are present in the opening of the womb and not apparent to the senses cannot be treated with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those among them which are present in the opening of the womb on which there is an impact from a sense [i.e., that can be perceived], those can be cured.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary, therefore, to put the woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then pull out the haemorrhoids with forceps or an abrasive cloth, cutting them from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then sprinkle on them near the flow of blood one powder from the cut up ingredients without mixing: such as acacia [gum arabic], dragon's blood [red resin], frankincense oil and similar things.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then push her feet to the wall for one hour.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Afterwards place her into cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	But if the bleeding persists then make her sit in a decoction of sumac [a flowering plant], pomegranate rinds, galls and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour and mix it with honey and vinegar to make a plaster from it on her back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If the blood stops with it then that's good; if not, attach cupping glasses to her back and breasts without scarifying [i.e., making incisions in her skin].
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool and soak it in the juice of thapsia [a toxic plant], or the juice of a stingray, or the juice of the branches of the oleander (i.e., dogbane), Pontic wine, and attach it with leather.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the abscess quiets down, then treat the area with ointments until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Barth, however, is red like the heads of garlic, and it has a rough appearance.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary, therefore, that you cut out what appears from it, as I said before regarding the equal edges; and treat it until it is healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	On the perforation of the cervix which occurs in the womb.
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter 74.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	There are many types of abscesses that occur in the womb, such as cancer, stony abscess, ulcer, scrofula, eczema, haemorrhoids, fistulas, anal fissure, and hot abscess.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I have indeed already described all these diseases and their types, as well as their signs and treatments, in the relevant sections; it is necessary for me to speak in this treatise about hot abscess which occurs in the womb from among the types of abscesses that discharge pus, and you wish to know how its incision with an iron instrument takes place.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary, therefore, for you to pay attention.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	Then if the abscess pain in its initial stage is sharp with its throbbing, and burning sensation, and fever; and you see it becoming red; if the sense of feeling falls upon it, then do not hurry with its incision; and treat it with what assists over maturation until such time as the severity of symptoms quiets down.
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is necessary that you make the woman sit on a seat washed with two seats, and reclines, or be propped up over her back, and she gathers her feet to the lower part of her belly; and her hips are spread out, and places both arms under her knees, and binds them with two appropriate ligaments to it.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then the midwife should sit on the right side and use the tool to open the maternal orifice.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose shape comes after them.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And when you want to use this tool, it is necessary that you insert the rod deep into the woman's womb, so as not to let what enters from the instrument go further than the depth of the womb and injure the patient.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	However, if the tool is longer than that depth, then you must place pegs on the cover of the womb's depth to prevent the tool from entering fully into the womb's depth and injuring the patient. It is necessary for the assistant to place the handle which runs in the tool above [or outside] and hold the tool while the assistant rotates the handle until the opening of the womb's depth.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	Once the emerging part is visible, can be touched by hand and feels soft and gentle, it must then be cut at its head with a wide spatula.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When the blood is evacuated, it must be treated with linen soaked in rose oil or green [resin] oil that has a certain styptic property; apply the linen and extract the piece from deep within the womb.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally over the womb and on top of the pubic hair clean wool soaked in warm water containing apples.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then it should be treated after two days with the ointment suitable for that until healing occurs.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the womb and wound are washed, such that they are cleansed with an enema of water and honey; then with water boiled with lily root or long aristolochia; before returning to ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If a wound is hidden internally within the womb, then one must refrain from treating it with iron instruments; rather, treat it with what we mentioned earlier in the section on [wounds of] division.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Treatise on Obstetrics: How to treat live embryos that emerge with an unnatural shape.
Caput Lxxu.	Chapter 70.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for midwives to recognize the form of normal birth first.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	Thus, the signs of this are as follows: when you see a woman pressing down with her lower body, and wanting to sniff the air, and what is above her relaxes, and she hastens the birth of the embryo: then know that this is natural childbirth, and it is an exit over its head, and the second stage is together with it; either suspended or hanging by the navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When you see these signs, then one ought to compress her abdomen so that the embryo descends quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	For when it descends over its head, the second stage descends with it, and is cleaned of those superfluities by a good cleansing.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Any birth other than this is unnatural, to be deplored.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	Sometimes a fetus emerges on its feet, and its body comes out before its head, with one or both of its feet and hands; or its head and hands come out; or the breech presents itself; and perhaps it turns over onto its neck, along with similar unnatural forms.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is thus necessary for midwives to be prudent and subtle in all these matters, and to beware of error and deception: and I am showing every form among them, and how it behaves within this, and what it signifies by that, and how one should sit on top of it [i.e., deliver the baby].
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus emerges on its own head and this causes great strain on the woman, making childbirth difficult for her, and you see her strength already weakened: then have her sit on a chair, or have other women hold her; and apply vapor of wool with fenugreek decoction and moist oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then the midwife should insert a small spatula between her fingers and tear the perineum with it, cutting it with her nail until all of its moisture runs out; and she should press on the woman's abdomen until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not descend, then the woman must be given an enema of fenugreek mucus with sesame oil.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then tell her to press herself together after the enema; make her sneeze with ground cumin, and hold her mouth and nose for an hour at a time.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus will come out immediately.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If the fetus's two hands come out first, you must join them together gently and slowly.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If it does not comply upon entry, then have the woman sit on a chair and raise her feet up; shake the chair onto the ground; and make sure the woman is held so she doesn't fall during the shaking.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If the hands still do not come out and the fetus dies, then cut them and extract the rest of the fetus; tie its hand with a cloth and draw it out gently; for it shall emerge.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The exitus of an embryo whose feet come first.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When a fetus comes out on its feet, then it should be pushed upward; the midwife should slowly turn it around and draw it forth equally.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then he should take one of his feet and stretch it slowly.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they therefore come out as far as the thighs, then bid him be compressed, and make him sneeze with force; for it will come out, if God pleases.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if it does not come out as we have described, then bring back the fetus little by little until you place it in its natural position.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For itself will then come out with an easy exit.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	But if it is hindered by all that we have described, then take from the mucilage of the Althaea plant, and oil of Sesamum, and dissolved gum; and beat all these things well in a mortar: then with this, anoint the woman's woolen apron and her lower belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make her sit in warm water until she feels it in the hypochondrium.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When therefore you see that her lower parts are now heated, then make a suppository of myrrh for her: and place it inside.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When therefore she has held the suppository for one hour, then make her sit upon a seat.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make her sneeze, and hold her mouth and nose shut; then press the lower part of her belly with a gentle pressure.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the fetus will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The exit of the fetus should be onto the knees and hands.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it comes out in this manner, then you should deliver by gradually inserting your hands.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman should lie down on her neck, and let her feet hang towards the floor; she should be lying on a bed, with her hands folded.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then press gradually upon her abdomen.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then remove what is beneath her feet from the mattresses, until she is prepared in the lower part (of the bed).
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the fetus does not exit, then take her feet and move them with a violent motion.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then press gradually on what is above the hypocondrium, until the fetus ascends towards the upper part (of the abdomen).
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then introduce your hands and equalize the fetus gradually; tell the woman to push down until the fetus exits (the birth canal).
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The fetus exits hanging horizontally from the hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	Her hand should be gently manipulated when being brought back down (to its normal position).
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If you cannot bring her hand back down, then lift the woman up and make her walk (around).
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she cannot walk, then make her lie on the bed; shake her legs with a violent shaking motion.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then apply the ointment you have prepared from the mucilages (linseed).
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If she has taken hold of the newborn, then make her sit on a chair (to recover).
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then strive to bring her hand back down and equalize the fetus according to its natural form; make the woman sneeze and tell her to push until it exits (the birth canal).
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The fetus's exit over its own neck, with hands spread out, and his face is toward his mother's back.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	The midwife must hold the fetus's hand; then she should gradually rotate it and equalize it with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is equalized, then place on its head what we described earlier from oil and mucilages.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then order him to move gradually.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done that, then make her sit on a chair and order her to lean to the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then order her to be compressed; and make her sneeze with pressure.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The fetus's exit prepared on its side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it descends to the uterine orifice with the afterbirth in this way, then cut the afterbirth with your nail until it is evacuated of moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended over the fetus's face and its neck, then cut it from the navel; so that it is not retained, and dies.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then push the fetus into the depths until you place it where it should be; and order the woman to compress herself several times; for it will indeed exit by a light passage.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins or of many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	Know that twins are often born; and sometimes three, or even four, are born.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	However, this is extraordinary, and rarely happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	There are five things that are beyond nature and do not truly live; though they increase in number, one caul contains them all, and the navel string separates each from its neighbour.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	And sometimes they are born as a single fetus through the natural and easy exit; or they may be born through the other unmentionable exit, as we have described.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If some of them are difficult at birth and come to that which we have mentioned as an unnatural presentation, then treat them as we have described; let there be a skilled midwife, who will act with skill and caution, and the child must be delivered according to every form with what is prepared for it in order to ensure its safety.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	A reminder of what is formed in the womb from embryos, some of which may be aborted.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	Sometimes one is formed in the womb, or two, three, four, five, six, seven, and even more - ten; I have already witnessed a woman who aborted seven fully-formed embryos, while another had aborted as many as fifteen.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	This was ascertained by the measurement of an illustrious sage.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	All this, therefore, ought to be within the knowledge of any obstetrician.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps it may happen to them in a similar way; so they should oppose this with what is necessary.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	On the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you treat a dead fetus as I have described regarding its extraction and it does not come out, and you are forced to use manual manipulation, then you must be mindful of the following.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If the woman is of sound virtue and is not afflicted by any of the conditions that pose a risk to her life, then she should lie on her back on a bed with her head tilted downwards and her legs elevated; an assistant should hold her from both sides or she should be tied to the bed so that her body is not dislodged during the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then moisten the mouth of the womb with moist oils mixed with marshmallow, fenugreek, and linseed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	The midwife should then anoint her hand with these oils and mixes; she can then easily insert it into the womb.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	She should then seek with her for the place where she can hook the fetus' limbs and suitable places to do so.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Therefore consider, if the fetus is ready to be delivered head-first: hook it by its eyes or neck, mouth, palate, under its chin, armpits, sides or below its ribs.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If, however, it is descending by its feet then hook it by the comb of its head or middle of its back.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	She should hold the hook with her right hand and place its curve between the fingers of her left; she can then easily insert her hand and secure the hook to one of those places mentioned until she reaches an empty space.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	Then she should hook another or even third if needed to ensure equal contraction and prevent any tilt towards one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	Then it should be extracted with equal traction and not just straight but rather moved to all sides so as to ease its exit; in the same way that a tooth is removed.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	And it must be softened where there is an interval between them to extend it.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	If a part of it is retained, then the midwife must anoint certain fingers with oil and insert them from that side so she can turn with them what has been retained.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	So if part of the fetus exits, then switch the hooks to another place that is higher: do this until the entire fetus exits.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If one hand exits before the other, and it's not possible to draw it back because of its contraction, then it must be wrapped with a cloth.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then draw it out until it exits completely; cut it either at the ankle or elbow joint: and so you must do this with the other hand and both feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	But if the fetus's head is large or it gets stuck during exit, or there's a build-up of water in its head, then one must insert between the fingers a spine-shaped spatula and cut open its head with it to draw out the water; or tear it apart using an instrument called Almisdac: whose form comes with forms of other instruments in the chapter that follows this.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Similarly, if the fetus is of a large-headed nature, then one must cut it with an instrument called 'algengematu': or draw it out with a misdach, as we've said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then you must draw the bones out with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If the head exits and gets stuck at the bifurcation, then it must be cut open until the moisture within the chest is emptied.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If it does not form a knot and fails to follow the path out, then cut open the head in pieces as best you can.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If there is an abscess in the lower abdomen or it is swollen with fluid, then you must pierce it until moisture flows out of it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If the fetus is positioned with its feet first, then it is easy to pull out and guide it towards the mother's pelvis.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If the obstruction is at the abdomen or chest, then you must extract it with a cloth wrapped around your hand; rip open the abdomen or chest until their contents flow out.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If the rest of its body is removed and only the head returns, then the midwife should insert her left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If the mother's pelvis is open, then the midwife should insert her hand deep inside and search for the head with her fingers, drawing it towards the mouth of the pelvis; next she must insert a hook or two hooks and pull it out with these.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If the mother's pelvis is constricted by a hot abscess, then you should not work on it but instead drain off moist and fatty substances; apply poultices and sit in softening and moisturizing waters.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus is on its side, then it may be brought straight; next do what we said for a live baby.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If this is not possible, then cut it into pieces and extract it.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And you must make sure that nothing of the afterbirth remains inside at all.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then apply what we said earlier for hot swellings that occur on the womb.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If there should be any bleeding, then apply styptic waters, and continue with the rest of the treatment.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	And I myself have seen a woman whose belly contained a dead fetus; afterwards she became pregnant again on top of it, later the other fetus also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	So it happened to her after a long time that there was a swelling on her navel and it became swollen until it opened up and started discharging pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to treat her, and I treated her for a long time; but the wound did not heal.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I placed on it some of the strongest drawing plasters; and a bone came out from that place.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Then after some days another bone came out too.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	So I wondered about it because there is no bone inside the belly.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought therefore that they were from the bones of the dead fetus.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	So I examined the wound and extracted many bones while the woman was in better condition; she has now lived like this for a long time, and only discharges very little pus from that place.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	And I did not record this here as something strange except that there is knowledge and help for the skilled physician who applies treatment with their hand.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	On the shapes of instruments necessary for extracting a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here is the form of the bookbinding tool by which books are squared up; it has two vertical rollers at either end of two pieces of wood that are equal in length.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	However, this vertical roller should be finer than that of the bookbinding tool, and for this purpose it can be made either of ebony or boxwood.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	The width of each piece of wood should be approximately two fingers; the edge of either end is one finger and the length of each is a palm and a half. In between the two pieces of wood are two smaller additions made from the same material whose length is a half-palm plus just a little more, and their width is about two fingers or slightly larger.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	These two smaller additions are inserted into the jaw of the frame so that it opens with them when you turn the two vertical rollers.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the roller that opens the frame.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another form similar to this one, but finer and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	It should be made of ebony or boxwood in the likeness of a pair of pincers.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	However, at its end there are two additions as you see above, and the length of each addition is about a palm; their width is approximately two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When you wish to open the frame with this tool, then have the woman sit on a bed with her feet hanging down and what is between her legs exposed.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Insert the two connected additions into the frame, holding the end of the tool between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, as you do with scissors, evenly according to the size of the opening of the womb's mouth, until the midwife does what she wants.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The form of another vertigo which they said was the same as that of something pushing, by which the fetus is pushed.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The form of the Almisdac by which the large head is crushed: and it resembles a pair of forceps with teeth at the end, as you can see.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	And sometimes it is made oblong, like forceps of this shape, as you can see, with teeth like a saw's, by which the head is cut and crushed.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of the Almisdac by which the small head is crushed.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The form of the 'Vuncus' with one spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of the 'Vuncus' with two spines.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The form of forceps with saw-like teeth by which the fetus's head is crushed.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of the 'Spatumilus' with two ends for cutting off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two wide 'Spatumili'.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	All these instruments are used and the more their types multiply and are prepared by the artisan, the faster they are for his procedure and the higher in esteem among people because of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Therefore, do not despise any of these instruments that is not prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	Indeed the need for them is undeniable.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	On the extraction of the secundine (amniotic sac).
Caput LXXVIII.	Chapter 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When secundine is retained during childbirth, you should instruct the woman to hold her breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make her sneeze with powder; press your hand over her mouth and nostrils.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it therefore comes out by this means, that is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not, then take a pot and make a hole in its lid; put into it herbs that open the womb's mouth, such as calament, rue, dill, chamomile, sage, woody cassia, and centaury: take all these herbs or some of them and immerse them with water, then place them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place a reed stick over the hole of the pot's lid and the other end into the womb's mouth; let her hold it until the steam reaches the womb's cavity.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make her sneeze as we said before.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	Indeed, the secundine will come out easily.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	But if it remains after this treatment and does not come out, then instruct the midwife to immerse her hand in oil of turpentine or marshmallow mucilage.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then she should insert her hand into the vulva and search for the secundine with it.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When she finds it, she should grasp it and gradually extend it.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If however it is attached deep inside the womb, then she should insert her hand as we described until finding the secundine and extract it slowly along its length so that the womb does not fall from a strong pull; rather, it needs to be turned gently to right and left sides: afterwards apply an amount of traction.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	Indeed, it then obeys, and is preserved, and comes away from adhesions.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	If the womb is contracted, as we have already explained: treat it with sneezing and with a medicated pot of herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	But if it does not come out with everything we have mentioned, then take care not to tire yourself out over it in the process of extracting it.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	But whatever comes out at the womb's opening from it, you should tie to the woman's thigh.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then give her an enema with the ointment tetrapharmacon.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	For it will indeed cause her to go bad after days, and be dissolved, and come out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	But when it goes bad, an unpleasant smell is raised from it to the belly and head, which harms the sick woman.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	Therefore, appropriate fumigations should be administered to it.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the ancients have already experienced the fumigation of watercress, and dried figs.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The shape of an instrument by which the woman is fumigated in the case of a retained afterbirth, and of menstruation.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	It should be made of a glass bottle similar to an alcama or out of zere: and the broad end is placed over the fire: and let the fumigation be set upon coals: hold it until that fumigation is consumed: and repeat another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	On the cure of anus which is not perforated.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter 79.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	Many boys are born with their anuses not perforated, which has already been skillfully plugged by a membrane.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	Therefore, it is necessary that the midwife perforate this membrane with her finger; and if not, she must do so using a sharp spade; taking care of the testicles, lest they be touched.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then place upon it wool soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	After that, treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	However, if you fear that it will become blocked again, then place a leaden tube in the hole for many days and remove it when the boy can defecate without difficulty.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And now an anal blockage also happens due to the scarring of wounds or from pus.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	Therefore it is necessary that this scar be cut open; then it must be treated in the same way as we have described for the treatment and lead.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	On the cure of fistulas that occur in the lower part [of the body].
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 80.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	The fistulas that occur below are nodules and swellings which arise near the anus on the outside; or they happen in the space of a single area; and there is one fistula, or several.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When this nodule has aged it is opened up; and from it runs a whitish watery fluid or thin pus.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And sometimes there arise penetrating fistulas from these.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	Penetrating fistulas are recognised by what comes out during defecation and flatulence, when the patient is suffering from diarrhoea; and perhaps worms come out of them.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	And there are among them fistulas that penetrate into the space reaching up to the bladder and up to the urethra of the penis.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And there are among them penetrating ones reaching up to the hip joint and up to the tailbone.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	From that by which a penetrating fistula up to the anus is recognized, there is also one that does not penetrate; you should insert your index finger into the anus and insert a thin probe of brass or iron into the fistula when it is not tortuous.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	If there is a tortuosity in it, then insert into it a thin lead probe or a horsehair until you feel the probe or the hair on your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel it penetrate fully and nothing comes out of the orifice in terms of discharge nor is there any windiness or worms as I said, then know that it does not penetrate; therefore, hasten to its cure.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	And when the fistula is penetrating up to the bladder or the urethra of the penis, its sign is that urine will come out from it and it being prevented from this so that the place might be consolidated with medicines.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	If it is penetrating up to the hip joint or the bone of the hip, then its sign is that a probe reaches there if there is no tortuosity in it all the way to the bone; and finding pain around that part, and pus always coming out from it: and that medicine does not hold in it nor can it be consolidated with ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And for all these penetrating fistulas there is no cure at all; and their cure is difficult and vain for the foolish doctors on whom they form.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	In non-penetrating wounds that are not old, healing is expected with a knife; as I tell you and have already proven; the patient lies on their back between your hands; elevate their legs up to above the hips and bend the hips towards their belly.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce a lead or brass probe until you know where the fistula ends.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	If however the patient feels it around the anus then you must introduce your index finger into the anus.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If therefore you feel the probe has penetrated and gone through what was detected, beyond what you feel between your finger and the fistula wall or flesh then you know for certain it is a penetrating wound; do not labor over it as there is no healing for it as we said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that flesh can heal and be of benefit to some men from medication; make a fine hot iron according to the size of the fistula as previously described and introduce it into the fistula until it reaches near the anus.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat this twice or three times until you know that all those added filtered flesh parts which are like a bird's quill have been cauterized.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then dress it with linen bandages steeped in butter until those cauterized flesh parts come out; then treat it with flesh-generating and consolidating ointments.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If therefore it heals then that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, then it will never heal with any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if the probe comes out at another spot and does not reach your finger that is inside the anus; there being between it and the place of issue a thick covering of flesh or a sifac: and you see a fistula in what follows along the surface of the skin, then cut away the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and proceed cutting with the probe that is in the fistula until the cutting reaches where the end of the probe comes to; and the probe is freed and falls out.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then cleanse those pieces of flesh which resemble the tube of a bird's quill so that nothing remains of them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	But if blood should overcome you and force a separation between yourself and your operation so that you have to desist from cutting those pieces of flesh; it is then better done and more quickly healing if you cauterize it with fire or with a caustic medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For a red-hot iron combines the good qualities of contracting the tissues it burns, checking the blood, and drying up the humors.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then dress it with lint wrapped in butter, or leaves that have been bruised until the place gives out pus and the burnt pieces of flesh come away into the pus.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then treat the wound with consolidating ointments that produce tough flesh; and these are medicines which have both an astringent and desiccating effect.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	For when they are restored, then already it is healed; and you need not fear repetition [of the dressing].
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	But if the fistula has already reached deep inside the anus and is drawn out by the redundancy of the body; then insert your finger into the anus, and probe with it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If you feel that there is a membrane or flesh between yourself and the patient, which is close to being penetrated, then an operation should not be performed unless it is along the path of trust and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	It is because one of three methods should be administered on it: either you cauterize it as we have said; or cut it away until you reach its concave shape so that it becomes possible for you to introduce the licinia and nearby cure.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed with the cutting too much so that you may not cut into the muscle containing the anus and it happens on the weak excretion of waste without consent.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cure it with what we have said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps it will be cured; or you may stretch the membrane and clean it after you cut it close to the anus as we said either with a probe or another sharp instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then clean those flesh fragments which are exposed by the cut until you can with scrutiny.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then attempt the restoration of the whole wound with cutting and superior opening where it hardens; and there remains a fistula open on the inside part of the anus, and will be lighter on the weak.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes a fistula follows in this way; that is when you introduce the probe into the fistula; and it is on the side of the anus about the surface of the body with skin and edge of the anus; then take the perforated end which is like a needle, namely preparing leather, according to this shape.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And introduce into it a thread rolled up of five threads, and about the same.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then introduce the probe with a thread into the fistula until it reaches its concavity.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If it is penetrating the margin of the anus internally close by, then extract the thread from that hole so that you insert your finger into the anus and withdraw the end of the thread and gather both ends together: and pull on each one, and leave it for a day or two days: and as much as the thread cuts into the flesh, tighten it well until those parts of the flesh which are between the two ends of the thread drop off: then treat the wound until it heals.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating then make it penetrate by whatever means prepares itself for you unless it be very deep.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	For it does not lie in your power to make that happen so that you do not cut into it.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound as we have said until it heals.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	Make a spatula with thorns which divides the fistula, whose curvature is very acute and one part of it is not acute so that it does not cut into what need not be, as you see.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	On the sewing up of haemorrhoids from which blood flows out due to their cutting: and on treating fissures.
Caput LXXXI.	Head 81.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	Haemorrhoids occur in two ways.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Or they occur inside the anus resembling bags of charcoal or plums or else like actual grains of wheat.
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	And they come small or large: and blood flows from them always either one alone or many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	There are some outside the anus and at its extreme ends.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	However, those that are outside the anus are mostly of little moisture, from which runs yellow water or a persistent flow of blood; and they correspond in colour to the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment for that which is inside the anus is to advise the patient to go and have a bowel movement; and it shall be expressed until it comes out of the anus, and you should see what appears to you.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore also hang them with hooks; or hold them with your nail.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if they do not hold in the hooks because of their moisture and softening; then take them with a rough cloth or with a cotton swab made from double-weave woollen material, and extract them with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them again, and sprinkle over them after cutting some hot powders, so that they remain in place as a caustic.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterise them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterisation.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then cure them with the remaining treatment until they heal.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	But if the anus does not comply with exiting, then give the patient an enema of a small dose of medicine, so that it washes away what is inside the anus, and complies quickly with exit when the patient evacuates.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If however they are extrinsic from the anus, then their case is light and easy; and it shall be that you take them with your nail or take them with a hook and cut them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Treat them with what we have described until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And for those who dread the cutting with an iron blade, you must administer stitches to them in this manner.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take some wound thread, and insert it into the needle.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw the needle towards you, and make it penetrate with its point from the other side; and wind two turns of thread around the lower part of the needle to be crossed laterally; then tie the needle firmly with a strong ligature.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and draw out the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the ligatures, leaving one of them; do not tie it too tightly so that excess blood may flow from it.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place over the wound a cloth soaked in rose oil or caarob syrup, and put it on the wound; and instruct the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then leave it there until it falls off.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When the ligatures have fallen off, treat them with ointments and the rest of their treatment until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	On the treatment of fissures.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Indeed they often happen due to drying out of the faeces and constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When they are thus hardened and medicine is of no avail, you must scrape them with the point of a spatula or your nail until they become moist, and remove from them the upper layer which prevents their healing.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then treat them until they heal as required.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If they do not heal, treat them again with greater force than the first time, until they bleed a lot and then dress them until they are healed.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	The treatment of inverted and not-inverted piles, and drying them with alum or ants.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter 82.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You should know that a pile is only a round knot, the same colour as the body, resembling the head of a nail; it can occur anywhere on the body, particularly in the lower parts of the feet and toes; they cause pain when walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is therefore necessary to cut what surrounds the head of the nail and hold it with forceps or a hook, then root out its base.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then treat it; if you wish, cauterise it according to what was prescribed in its own chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	A dry pile is a small, rough elevation, like a grain, raised above the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	They often occur on children's hands.
