Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	Limbs putrefy either from an external or internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	Therefore when you have treated that corruption with medicinal cure and it does not respond to the treatment; and you see the corruption spreading into the limb in such manner that it is not repelled by anything: then it is necessary that you amputate that limb up until where the spread of the corruption follows, so that the patient may escape death or some more serious malady through loss of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	The sign that this has occurred is when the limb turns black and is considered burnt by fire or undergoes putrefaction after turning black; until that rot is cut away as far as the bone which follows that limb, and spreads throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, the treatment should be with an incision of it, and similarly if the cause of the corruption is from the stings or bites of certain venomous creatures such as the marine scorpion, viper, rutella, and similar animals.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore the corruption or sting is at the tip of the finger, then cut off the finger and do not give any space to the corruption, so that it does not spread further into the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it occurs in the hand, then cut it off from the wrist and do not give any space to the corruption until it reaches the elbow of the arm.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades further, then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	But if the corruption passes through and you see it around the elbow, then for that patient there is death.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And apart from that in terms of treatment, it's the amount of strength which matters.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do the same with the foot when corruption invades a toe; then cut it off at one of its joints. And if it reaches the instep of the foot, then amputate the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	But if it climbs up to the knee, then cut off the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If however the corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill left other than to give up and leave the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	The method for cutting a limb or sealing it is to tighten the ligament below where you want to cut; and then tighten another ligament above that spot.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And the attendant should stretch one ligament downwards; and the attendant should stretch another ligament upwards, towards the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with a broad knife, until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it may be cut or sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	You should place a piece of linen cloth on all sides so that the knife does not touch the healthy area; otherwise, an additional injury may occur in the weakened spot and pus will form.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If there is internal bleeding as you operate, then quickly cauterize the spot; or place some blood-stanching powders on it.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and take care of it until it is healed.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you that this same accident happened to a man on his foot.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	Which was because his foot turned black with a burn that looked like it had been set alight by fire; and the corruption first started on his toe before spreading to his entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	The man therefore treated himself after he saw the corruption take hold of his limb with great pain and burning; it started at the join and he healed up.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	After a long time had passed, the same corruption occurred to him on his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I tried to treat the excess with what I had placed on his hand from medicines after cleansing his body; however, the excess was not reabsorbed and began to spread to another finger until decay set in on his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He thus called for me to amputate his hand; I refused, hoping that it would be reabsorbed and fearing death for him even if I were to perform the amputation on his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the strength of the man was above the injury.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he lost hope in me, he returned to his land; and by the time it reached me that he had hurried there and cut off his entire hand, I found him healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	I have not presented this account except to offer help for those who suffer from this kind of illness; and also as a sign by which it may be recognized, so that one can proceed accordingly.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the treatment of worms, and the quality of enemas with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a pus-filled swelling occurs on certain fleshy parts of the body and the swelling continues to spread until it collects some pus; then it bursts or is pierced, and whatever was inside leaks out, leaving behind an empty space like that of a pot, while the skin above remains like cloth that has been worn thin: if this does not reach its last stage in decay nor cause damage to bone, nerve or ligament, it merits being called a Worm; but not a Fistula. However, when the process continues until the corruption penetrates one of these parts, then it is properly called either a Fistula or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	The cure for it is to cut the entire skin as it peels off and especially when it becomes thin like cloth; you can be confident that it will not stick back into place because of its degeneration.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	However, if you expect the skin to adhere and it doesn't lead to that ultimate deterioration; and if there is a thickening of flesh in the skin, then treat this with an enema and consider the sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	If it is large and the pus that comes out of it has a foul odor, then enema it with Egyptian medicine, which consists equally of vinegar, oil, and ziniar, combined in a vase; boil over fire until the medicine turns red and becomes as thick as honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Take as much of it as you need; dissolve it with water and honey and enema the sinus with this solution, then close off the opening and leave the medicine inside for about two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with pressure; do this for as many days as needed until the sinus is cleansed and the stench removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	Sometimes it can be enema'd with ash water if this medicine is not available; in that case use the ashes of grape-wood or oak-wood and sprinkle them over the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then mix it and enema with it until you're confident that the sinus has been cleaned out.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate Egyptian medicine or ash water, then enema them with just water and honey, to which you should also add some powdered ziniar.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or apply the enema itself mixed with honey and wine since it is a property of honey to cleanse and wash away, and the wine makes the bowel adhere, especially when there is an excess of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this a few times, and are confident that the bowel's corruption has been removed, then apply an enema with what makes flesh grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And you may take some of the dyafinicon plaster; dissolve it with rose oil and astringent wine; or apply an enema with certain medicines and other ointments whose properties I have written about in my treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	But if the bowel's orifice is narrow and cannot admit the enema pipe, then dilate it slightly with an iron instrument; or apply to it a linen cloth wrapped around an Egyptian ointment, or a royal ointment, until it has been enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the orifice is also wide, then draw together its lips with a suture; and leave such an extent of it as will admit an enema without extension.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if its orifice from which the pus flows is elevated upwards, then cut it lower down where the pus oozes out so that it will flow downwards; for when pus is confined deep within a bowel, it prevents flesh from forming there.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But if you cannot cut the bowel as low down around it as you wish, then try to prepare the member in such a way that the pus may flow from it with ease as is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try to ensure that no pus remains in it at all; and take consolidating medicines which are applied to a wound, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the cloth be of such quantity that it covers the entire breast.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with scissors along a straight line from the nipple hole, slightly larger than the breast opening.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread a soft ointment on another cloth, according to the size of the hole; and place it over itself in a distant position from the breast opening, so as to alleviate the discharge of pus from it: and do not remove the large cloth unless after some days at once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	Now the one which is over the breast opening, that is the one you remove every hour, so as to drain what accumulates in it of pus: and so that you may know if that which flows from it matter is abundant or scarce; thick or thin.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this again consider the place of the breast itself, if its owner feels pain there, or not; and whether there is inflammation, or no inflammation.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is prolonged like this, and you see the matter which comes out over the breast opening, then you know that the breast has already adhered, or approaches adhesion: then therefore release it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you release the wound, then change the other cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	But if a thin matter comes out of the breast after a long time, then do not despair about its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, since there are men who delay flesh production in their wounds, and among them are those who act contrary to it.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if unabsorbed pus comes out of the breast after many days, then you know that the breast does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If the adhesion of the sinus is delayed and its condition prolonged, then add to the drying medicines, but let the physicians ensure that the medicines are moist in their substance and dry in their virtue, such as dyaphinicon ointment when an excess of zegi is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And for the final treatment, take some dyaphinicon ointment and dissolve it with rose oil, then rub it on old wine equal in quantity to the substance of the ointment.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix the two together and use them.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And you may do something similar to this procedure when dyaphinicon ointment is not available; instead use honey, which you should boil until it thickens, and then use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, aloe, and olibanum; pound all three together, then powder them over honey while it is still on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then spread a cloth over it and bind it to the sinus; spread over this the honey that you boiled until thick, and powder spices over it before placing another cloth on top and binding them together.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	At times, long aristolochia, roots of celestial lily (that is, saffron), comfrey root flour and centaurea may also be administered.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use these ingredients either individually or combined; pound them together and sieve before powdering over the honey I previously described, then use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the condition of the sinus persists and does not heal with this treatment, then know that there is some deep-seated corruption; or it may have already affected bones, other hard tissues, or ligaments; in such cases treat it according to the fistula treatments I outlined previously.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	The treatment for panaritium and an abraded nail involves incision or amputation of the finger.
Caput XCI.	Chapter 81.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A panaritium is an abscess that forms under the nail of the thumb or big toe, although it may also appear on other digits.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When left untreated and neglected for too long, the abscess can become inflamed with heat or become infected, discharging pus until it erodes the nail root; it may destroy the entire nail bed entirely, spreading to the bone, causing foul odours; the digit's extremity becomes swollen and discoloured.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	Therefore, when your treatment does not help as described above, it is necessary to cut away with a knife all that remains of the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Afterwards, cauterise the wound.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	Indeed, hot-iron cauterisation is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	However, if the bone is sound and both nail and nail bed are healthy but empty nail appendages now push flesh towards the interior and begin to pierce it, causing harm; then you must place a slender probe beneath that nail corner which pricks the flesh and push back on it; cut away this flesh with ease and put on what remains of corrosive cauterising salves until all is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Afterwards treat it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If the infection has already reached the bone, it is necessary to cut away and remove this bone; for it will never heal as long as the corrupted bone remains.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see decay and deterioration spreading into the finger, then cut it off at one of the joints, according to what has been previously mentioned.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If the nail is damaged by scraping or knocking, and there is severe pain in it, then you should first bleed the patient with a lancet.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then cut away the nail with a sharp spatulum, cutting it transversely from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And be careful not to cut through into the flesh that lies underneath the nail, for you will cause a severe pain to happen to the patient, and it will lead to an addition of flesh growing there.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then treat the place with something that soothes pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	However, the added finger that grows on some people's hands may be all flesh; and there may be bones in it sometimes, or a nail may grow with it; and some of them are born at the root of the joint, while others start growing from one of the knuckles of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	The one which grows from the knuckle of a finger does not move; and the one that is born at the root of the joint may or may not be able to move it.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	The one which is all flesh among them is easy to cut off.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	This means you should cut it at its root with a broad spatulum.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	The treatment of the one whose growth is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Refrain from making an incision on it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	However, if one is born with it on the tip of the finger near the last joint, then you should first cut its flesh with a round incision until you reach the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw through the bone using one of those saws suitable for this purpose.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	After that, take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	However, the condition which occurs in fingers due to being close together happens often either from birth, i.e., they are born like that, or from healing of a wound, or burning by fire and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary to cut away the joining flesh until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen cloths or pieces of cloth soaked in rose oil so that they do not join together quickly and separate the fingers; or place a thin sheet of lead between them until the affected area has healed as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if such a condition occurs in some fingers with the palm of the hand then cut away the joined flesh according to what is prepared and suits the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On the surgical correction of deformity.
Caput XCII.	Chapter 92.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	There are twisted veins filled with a lot of melancholic waste which appear in many body parts and their end point is often the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk long distances or do heavy labour.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	It is therefore necessary that one administers strong beating of the body to expel the black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then the leech should take care of the patient's basilica.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The treatment of these with iron, however, is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they should be cut open, and black blood extracted.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other method is that the vein should be raised up, and removed in its entirety.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its incision is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Scrape the leg first with warm water until the thick, dirty blood is loosened.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the patient's leg from the upper part of their hip to the lower part of the knee with a cloth.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then cut the vein at one place or two, or three places, with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise it up, that is to say extract the blood with your hand from the lower part of the leg upwards, and you must have the patient's leech at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then cut the nail down to below: until you see a quantity of blood exiting that is sufficient and which the patient's strength can tolerate.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Afterwards bind this up; and order him to abstain from foods which produce black bile; and repeat the evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full of it, as long as it does not harm the patient.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its elevation is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrape the patient's leg if there is much hair on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse him in a bath; or scrape it with your hand on the patient's leg with warm water until he turns red and the veins fill up; or make him exercise vigorously if there is no bath present for him, until his limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then make an incision through the skin along the length of the vein: either at its lowest point near the knee or on its lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then lift the skin with hooks and scrape out the vein from all sides until it appears to the senses; when you see that it is red and darkening.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it has receded from the skin, you will see that it is white like a string.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce a rod under it until when you lift it up, it comes out of the skin; hang it with a blunt hook gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make another incision near that incision, three fingers away.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then lift it up with rods as you did before, and hang it with another hook just as you did initially.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another incision or several incisions if required.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then lift it up, and make an incision at the last part near the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract it to the incision above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you extract it from the upper incision or all higher incisions when it comes out completely; then cut it open.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	But if it does not obey you and rise up for extraction; then introduce a needle with strong thread twice through, and tie it before extracting or put a rod under it again; roll your hand in all directions until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it becomes difficult for you to raise it greatly, and it enters the patient from that harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	So when you have extracted it all: then place over the wound a piece of wool soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil; and treat it until it is healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	But if the artery is twisted, having a turn to the sides, and it is not as we have said straight: then you must cut over it on every side of its twist, and the places of its turn.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then lift it with hooks until you have raised it all; and beware near your cut over it that you do not cut the vein or wound it; for it will be difficult for you to raise or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, preserve your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The incident in which the artery is healed.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of a blind wound.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It does not have a curvature like other wounds, nor is it of sharp point so as not to wound the vein; and it has a thick bend, gentle: for if it were thin, it would cut the vein with its thinness; rather let there be superfluous thickness to it, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter 93.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as Alizegi, and the land of the Arabs; and in dry, hot lands of little tenderness, that is, where neither grass nor tree are born.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it generates in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	Indeed its generation is from the putrefaction which happens beneath the skin, just as it happens inside the bodies of snakes and roundworms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	A sign of the beginning of this condition is a severe inflammation that occurs in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then cauterize the area.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to exit from that place of cauterization, like it is a root of a plant or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When its end appears, you should wrap around it a piece of lead weighing from one to two drachmas, and tie that in place; then leave the lead hanging from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever anything emerges from it to the outside, wrap that in lead and tie it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	But if it extends for too long, cut off that part and wrap the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it away entirely until all of it has emerged.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut it away too soon, it will contract and reenter the flesh; this can cause an abscess, or even decay of the flesh around that place to a nasty ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it should be handled gently and extracted gradually until all of its length is out; in some men, this vein may measure as much as five to ten palms.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	He has now reached a point where he exited the man through twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if it happens to you during your treatment time: then insert a rod into its hole and perforate it with a long hollow needle until all the material inside is evacuated; and apply decay-causing medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then treat it with the treatment of abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the ankle joint or on the foot itself; and it happens to have multiple openings, with a branch exiting from each opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore treat it as we have said in the section above, and along with what has been mentioned before.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On cutting open on worms generated under the skin, which is called asinine disease.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 94.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This disease is called asinine disease in our country; therefore, because it often happens to donkeys and there is a small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it enters the entire body, going up and down; and it is felt by the person when it moves from limb to limb until it bursts wherever it bursts through the skin, and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	Its generation is from the decay of certain fluids.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happens with worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and pinworms in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared for its harmfulness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	When he goes into the body and is lifted up to the head, and reaches a certain place, then perhaps he opens it up, comes out, and destroys the eye; this happens many times.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Thus when you want to treat him and take it out, this does not happen unless during his walking around and the appearance of its symptoms to [your] senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore you must bind what is above him and what is beneath with a strong ligamentary constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut just above it and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	But if [the stone] is buried within the flesh and you do not find it, then place a hot iron on that spot until [the patient] dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater danger to be feared is its corruption, by which it destroys the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see that it has already reached the head near to the eye, then bind underneath it a good strap across the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then cut just above it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And the patient must use cleansing of his body with medicines that dissolve evil foul humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he should avoid foods that cause putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On the cutting [treatment] of Nakir's illness.
Caput XCV.	Chapter 95.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This illness is called Nakir in our land, and it is a pain that occurs in some members; then it shifts from one member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I myself have indeed seen it, just as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to an ailing woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found that her arm was swollen, and I saw a small enlargement in the vein of the biceps.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I remained for an hour, I saw one swelling advance with its feelers, moving like a worm, climbing to her shoulder faster than can be believed: so that it was like live silver, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So the pain receded from that spot, and became fixed in her shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then I sat for an hour, and it ran into the rest of her body until it reached her other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then she told me that it was revolving throughout her entire body, just as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	So I marveled at the speed of its transformation from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I myself had never before seen this illness with my own eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many whose pain shifts from limb to limb; and I had not witnessed it with my eyes as I saw it in the woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think it to be anything other than what it is because the woman was one of those from dry villages whose veins are easily detected; thus that shift in sensation appears windy.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that this reasoning does not appear to apply to those who are lush and have moist bodies with hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you wish to cure it and the patient feels that pain: then if it is apparent to your eye as we said before, then compress above and below it quickly: and cut above it until the trapped wind escapes: and cauterize the area.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see it with your eyes: then treat it with body shaking, and with what expels wind, and causes it to belch foul smelling pills, and pills made of serapin, and similar.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter 96.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their type, and the locations within the body where they fall.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their differences are as follows: for among them there are those with large heads and small ones: concave and convex.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And some have three edges.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And among them, there are those with barbs.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And some have feathers.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those according to the limbs within which they fall are of two kinds.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	For the limbs are either among those that are concave members such as the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, bladder and similar.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When it falls into any of these limbs and you see the signs of death I describe below, then you must avoid extracting that arrow from them, for death will follow that person in whom it is in many cases.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the limb, then extract it and treat the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when an arrow strikes the brain and penetrates the bone, and emerges from the soft part that is above the brain, these are the signs: severe headaches occur, and also scotomata, vertigo, redness of eyes, swelling, reddening of tongue, spasms, confusion, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood emerges from the nostrils or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is impaired, and the voice becomes hoarse.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	From the place of the wound, white moisture like pus emerges.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there is an exit from it similar to the moistness of flesh.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it has not emerged.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow having struck the heart are that it is close to the left nipple, and he feels with it as if it were fixed in a hard thing, not in an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of the arrow is similar to the pulse; and black blood runs out from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	After that follows extreme coldness, and cold sweat, and fainting.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Therefore you should know that death is undoubtedly near.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	The signs of an arrow having struck the lung are that blood emerges from the wound in a frothy manner; and the veins which follow around the neck become inflamed, and the colour of the patient changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	He expires with a great, deep breath and seeks to draw in cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow strikes the membrane that is in the chest, then it is near the small ribs; and there will be great panting with severe pain, accompanied by a sigh; and all the limbs of the shoulders will move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if the arrow strikes the stomach, then perhaps some undigested food will exit from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if the arrow strikes the belly and pierces it, then perhaps some feces will exit from the wound, or a fragment of the bowl, or an intestine that is already ruptured.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is therefore no hope for its cure nor for extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow strikes the bladder and urine exits from it, and something from within proceeds to the exterior, and the pain is more severe in the lower region, then know that this is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining body parts, such as the face, neck, throat, jawbone, aid, spine, shoulder blade, hip, leg, and similar members, are healed according to many procedures when the arrow has not struck an artery or nerve, and the arrow is not poisoned.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I have seen these very arrows so that you may know by them regarding your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is to say, an arrow struck a man's tear duct at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it myself from the other side, below the ear fat; and he was healed, and there was no harm done to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	I extracted another arrow from the eye of a Jew; it had fallen into the fat under his lower eyelid and was already obscured. I only found its tiny tip, which adhered to its wooden shaft, and this was a large arrow used by Turkish archers with a blunt iron head without any barbs.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was healed so no evil accident befell his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab arrow with barbs.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	So I cut open the throat from both sides and the arrow was already submerged there.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I handled it carefully until I extracted it; the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	I extracted another arrow from the belly of a man which had fallen there; we thought he would die because of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed without his condition changing in any way, I cut over the arrow and contrived a plan to remove it; he was healed and no evil accident befell him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	I saw a man whose back had been wounded by an arrow; the wound had healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	Seven years later, the arrow emerged from his hip joint.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	I saw a woman who had an arrow in her belly; the wound had healed over it and the arrow remained inside her body without changing anything about her condition. The woman did not find any harm to herself through her normal bodily functions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	I saw another man who had an arrow shot into his face; the wound had healed but remained, causing him little pain; there were many similar cases to these.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from the nose of a man who was one of the king's lords; it had gone into his nose and had started to turn towards the right side somewhat; the whole arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was called to treat him three days after he got hit with the arrow.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Thus, I found the wound of the arrow to be very tight-fitting.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I therefore examined it with a thin probe, and did not feel the arrow; for he himself found the point of entry and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that this was caused by the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	So I plastered the place with a plaster possessing both drawing and digesting powers, trusting that the spot would form an abscess so that I could cut over it; but this did not occur to indicate whether or no the arrow had gone into the skull.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I kept plastering him for many days; but nothing happened and the wound had healed in the meantime; so he remained weak from the extraction to this day because of that event until one day he felt an arrow inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me about it.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	Therefore I placed a sharp corrosive medicine on the wound for many days until it opened; and when I probed with a probe, I felt an extremely thin end of the arrow which was stuck to some wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added the sharp medicine to open up the wound until we visibly saw the tip of the arrow; and it took about four months with him for this to happen.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged and it was possible to insert the forceps into it, and move them without yielding an exit: I did not cease from applying a scalpel and devising methods with instruments until one day I began on it with forceps that were suitably made, according to which their form will come at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that cartilage of the nose is not restorable.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore I restored it, and the wound was consolidated and he healed with complete health: nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the nature of extracting certain arrows: so that you may have this as a rule and sign over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not covered with the narration: nor does the book cover it, and a prudent craftsman compares little to much: and what is present to what is absent: and finds new methods, and new instruments from foreign matters of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then, that arrows do not exit from the limbs in which they are fixed except by two methods.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction out of the place where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by contraries of the other parts.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which exits from where it entered is either an arrow proceeding through fleshy tissue; and it is drawn out, and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to removal from the time when it strikes; then you should leave it alone for several days until the flesh surrounding it becomes putrid; and its drawing out and exit will be eased.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it lodges in bone and does not yield to your removal attempts; then leave it alone for several days as well; and repeat the drawing out and movement each day until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it still does not yield to your removal attempts after those days then you must bore around the arrow on all sides within the bone itself with a fine trepan until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out, and extract it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is lodged in the skull bone and has already penetrated one of the ventricles of the brain; and some of those symptoms which I mentioned become apparent then refrain from drawing out the arrow, and leave it until it becomes calm after several days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the Sifach (an internal organ), then death is not prolonged for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not lodged except only within the substance of a bone; and it has not penetrated as far as the Sifach; yet he remains unwell for several days, and none of those symptoms occurs to him: then make an effort in drawing out that arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is lodged very firmly and does not yield to your drawing attempts then apply the trephine around the arrow as I described earlier; then treat that place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is already hidden within the body and concealed from detection by the senses, you must then seek it out with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you sense it, then draw it out with certain instruments suitable for the extraction.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot proceed with the extraction due to the narrowing of the wound and the arrow's depth, and if there is no bone or nerve present near it, then wait until its extraction becomes possible by enlarging the wound.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If there are barbs attached to it that can be grasped, then free the flesh stuck around them from all sides with any tool available for the purpose; and if you cannot achieve their release due to embeddedness of the flesh in the barbs or contortion of the barbs, wait until the wound becomes enlarged enough for its extraction.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	As you proceed with the arrow's extraction from any location it is in, use hand contortion and forceps to pull on all sides until its emergence; do so with utmost care lest the arrow be broken or its extraction made more difficult for you.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot proceed with its extraction within one hour, then abandon it for a few days until the flesh around it becomes rotten.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the extraction process; for it becomes easier by then due to rotting of the flesh around it. If you face difficulty with blood flow during this process, apply the method described in its dedicated chapter earlier on in this book. And be mindful of your skills so as not to damage veins or nerves or tendons in the body.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	Apply any method possible to achieve its extraction; and let it be done with ease and calmness or slowness and firmness as I described earlier to you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	You must make sure that when you remove the arrow, the patient is positioned according to the figure, just as they were at the time of impact by the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Since it is more beneficial.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If you cannot do that, then use one of the figures which is possible for you.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	An arrow that emerges from the opposite side of the other part, or has already penetrated somewhat outwards: if the tip of the arrow causes a swelling on the upper surface of the skin nearby and you see it protruding, cut over it; let your incision be according to the length which will permit forceps to grasp its end.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then pull it out, for by then the arrow is easily removed.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it is retained inside the bone, then turn your hand according to its curvature until you feel the arrow pushing against the bone and enlarging itself; afterwards pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not, leave it alone for several days; afterwards try again until you remove it.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If there is any wooden part of the arrow still inside it, then push that forward with it as well.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if the wooden part has broken off and you wish to administer a push using an instrument, then insert into it a concave tool so that its cavity fits over the tail of the arrow; afterwards push with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is concave, then use an instrument to push against it as it enters inside it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	Indeed the arrow will be eased by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then you should scoop out all the concave flesh where the poison is; if this is possible for you to do.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then treat it with what suits it best.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow has fallen into the chest, or belly, or bladder, or side: and it is close enough that you can reach it with a hook, and it's possible for you to cut above it; then cut, and take care to avoid veins or nerves while extracting it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then stitch the wound if you see fit, and treat it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the shape of the forceps with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	The ends should be like the beak of a bird, which are made to look like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not release it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And there are many types of them made, large and small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, its slenderness, and the width or narrowness of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	The shape of an impelling concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of a deafening impeller.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the end of a deafener that looks like a spoke so as to smoothen its entrance into the concave arrow, and impel it with this.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The end of this concave impeller is concave like a bird's feather so as to smoothen the arrow's entrance into it and its impulsion.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the cutting of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 97.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins that have become accustomed to being bled.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Out of which there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins that lie behind the ears and are known as "the two herbs"; and two arteries visible at the two temples; and two veins lying at the two tear ducts of the two eyes, called 'the lookers'; and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which lies at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two Guidegis, which lie in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are located on the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that lie on the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are veins called 'Algecherich'.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins that lie beneath the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	However, there are five veins that may be bled on each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalic vein, and it lies on the side of the arm; and the people call this the head vein.
Et Fusca.	And there's another one called the 'Fusca'.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	There is also the Median vein, which is composed of a branch of the Basilica and a branch of the Cephalic; and the people call this one 'the body vein'.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	There is also the Basilica which lies on the inside of the arm; it's called the 'Titillicaris' as well.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the people call this one 'the belly vein'.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	The tendon of the biceps is placed on top of the operating table and it is where venesection takes place; it becomes visible over the thumb as an obvious protrusion.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	The cephalic vein, which is between the ring finger and little finger, has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	There are three veins in the calf and foot.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is the one that runs beneath the curve of the thumb on the side closest to the forearm.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	The second is the saphenous vein, which is located at the heel on the inner side of the foot.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The nerve vein is situated at the heel on the outer side of the foot.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	There are also three similar veins in the other leg.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On venesection of two veins behind the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	Venesection of the two veins behind the ears is beneficial for old catarrhs, headache, eye problems, and long-standing head ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	The procedure of venesection should be as I describe it.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	The patient's head should be shaved, and their occipital region rubbed at the site of the two veins with a coarse cloth using vigorous friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the patient should tightly tie their neck with a cord until the two veins become visible.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	The sites of these veins are behind the ears, in the two hollows of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Feel for them with your finger and wherever you feel their pulse beneath your finger, mark that spot with a cautery iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the surgical knife, which is called 'the cutter'.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce the blade beneath the vein on the skin until you reach the surgical knife's edge.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Next lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut through the vein and skin with a single cutting motion.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	Let the length of the cut be equivalent to two joined fingers, or around that amount; and make as much blood exit as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then press it with pads, and leave it until it is healed.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And already at the beginning of this book I mentioned how to make such an incision, and its cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On double arterial venesection for fevers.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	The benefit of double arterial venesection on the two pulse points is for old headaches; and for those with bad sores, and continual eye discharge from excess moisture.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the way of performing this venesection is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient should press their neck very hard until two veins appear clearly to the eye; and their pulse is shown beneath your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then mark these with an iron cautery.
