And some of them said: it is necessary that the wound be covered with wool that has already been soaked in warm oil; and they should place little pellets between the ribs until it is full, so that there may be an equal binding when you wrap it around according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	Afterwards the patient should be treated for pleurisy with food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	But if the patient is severely oppressed by it and cannot tolerate it, and when we open up the bandage their mouth is injured by the sharp object, and we fear for the patient; then we must cut open the wound and expose the broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	Then we should place on it the instrument for healing a fracture, which has been mentioned previously; and we cut through the bone with ease, and we set the broken ends together.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	Afterwards we should bring together the two lips of the wound, if it is large with a stitch; and we heal it with plasters until it is cured.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	But if a hot abscess should occur meanwhile, then hasten and pour little pellets into rose oil, and place it on the wound; and the patient will be treated for an abscess with what is suitable to its condition.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	Meanwhile they should also lie on their side until it heals.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	On the restoration of fractures of the vertebra of the back and neck.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	Indeed fractures of the bones of the neck sometimes occur; and they rarely suffer abrasion, just like the vertebra of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	When this happens to someone and you want to know if they will recover or not, then consider the following factors.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	If you see that their hands have become soft and numb, and dead; they cannot move them, stretch them or grip with them; and when you squeeze them with your fingers and prick them with a needle, they do not feel it and there is no pain: then know that they will not recover, and in most cases this condition is fatal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	But if they can move them and feel the grip with their fingers and the pricking [with a needle]: then know that the bone is undamaged, and that the patient will recover with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the same condition affects the vertebrae of the back, and you want to know if they will recover or not, then consider their feet: if you see that these have become soft, and what happens in them is similar to what happens in the hands, and when they lie on their back wind goes out and waste comes out without control; and when they turn onto their belly, waste comes out without control; and when they turn onto their back again, and want to urinate but cannot: then know that it is fatal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	Therefore do not trouble yourself with treating them.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	If none of this happens to them, the condition is less serious.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	And the treatment for this condition is to apply a soothing poultice of warm compresses; so that you place on the affected vertebra only rose oil mixed with ground beef.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	Apply this several times a day until the warm swelling subsides; then place over it one of the tightening, drying plasters and bind it tightly with a bandage: and instruct the patient to rest and remain calm.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	He must not sleep on the side where he finds pain until it is cured.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	If this happens due to the grinding of bone splinters or something that has already separated from it, then you must cut above the skin and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound, if it is large, with stitches.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with any flesh-colored ointment until it is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	But if the last bone of the hip is broken and it is the end of the tailbone: then you must put your left thumb into the anus, and with the other hand equally align the broken bone as far as possible, and do this a second time.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then place something over it, remove it, and treat the wound with the previous cure until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	On restoration of the anus.
Caput XI.	Chapter 11.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	Bones of the anus rarely break.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	If they do break, then their fracture is not a break but rather crushing at the ends; and they are split lengthwise and fall into the bowel; and it happens that the patient feels pain in the place, and an ache; and the leg that was broken goes to sleep.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And its restoration is that you must extend your hand over it until you feel the fracture as shown in the figure.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	If the fracture is only at its ends then align that fracture according to what is prepared for you in the figure until it resembles its natural shape.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	If the fracture is longitudinal or has already shifted inward, then have the patient lie on their stomach until you prepare to repair the fracture.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	When you have therefore equalized it, place a plaster cast upon it; then put on top of it a splint made of wood or leather, and bind the binding firmly over which you fear no change in the fracture nor displacement of the splint.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	Evenly compress the concavity with that which fills it until the binding takes hold of it equally; and instruct the patient to sleep on their back or on their healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	If a hot swelling should occur, then cease extending it and repairing it until the hot swelling subsides; and place on top of it what sits upon it as previously described, then return to its repair; and bind it as necessary.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	If there is splintering of the bone or shattering, extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	On the repair of a broken arm.
Caput XII.	Chapter 12.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	The splint is that which is between the elbow and the head of the spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	If it breaks, its repair is by one of two methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	One of which is to take a flat piece of wood, half the thickness, in this shape that follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	And bind two bindings at both ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	Then hang it from an elevated place; and have the patient sit on a chair.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	He should then place his broken arm on a wooden support until he reaches his little finger, in the middle of which is attached the curved part of the wood.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	Then hang something heavy above it so that it stretches out his arm downwards.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	Then the doctor should align the fracture with his hands until it returns to its proper place.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	Another method is to have the patient lie on their back with their neck bent backwards; then hang his arm from his own neck using a strap.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	Instruct two assistants to hold it; one above the fracture with his hands and the other below, each pulling in their own direction.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	And if you want a stronger extension, then bind below the fracture with one strap and above it with another; each of the two assistants should pull in their own direction.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	If the fracture is near the shoulder joint, then one strap should be placed below the little finger and another below the fracture towards the elbow.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	Similarly, if the fracture is near the elbow joint, then a strap should be placed above that point and another above the elbow itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	Then align the fracture easily without effort until it is properly aligned and well set; then bind it if there is no hot swelling.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	If there is hot swelling, then leave the binding until the seventh day.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	And place on it a woolen compress soaked in vinegar and rose oil until the swelling subsides; then bind it; the method of binding is to apply a plaster over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	Then place a bandage made from new cloth over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	Then bring their arm up for support, and place their open hand over their shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	And place the cloth and secure it tightly over their arm as a splint, so that the arm remains fixed in position; if nothing hinders you from doing this, then no part of the broken bone will shift against you.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	If you fear that something from the broken bone might shift against you, then use splints; and it is best to place over the fracture itself a splint which is wider and stronger than the other splints.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	And place your finger between the width of each splint; and let the length of the splints be according to the fracture with an additional three fingers' breadth on either side.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	Then bind tightly over the splints using the binding I mentioned at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	And it is best that your binding be tighter over the area of fracture itself.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	And the more the fracture extends, let your binding be less tight.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	If therefore you see that the splints and binding are placed as we have said when you restore their limb just now, then do so; and if you fear a hot inflammation, then loosen the binding and remove the splints until the seventh day, as we mentioned.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	Then inspect the ligature every three days so that there is no itching or swelling at the site, nor does food fail to reach the limb due to excess binding.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	Therefore correct everything according to what we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	If it is with confidence that nothing will happen from it, then do not remove the ligature unless after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	And if the patient's sleep is on their back with their hands over their stomach, place beneath them as a pillow a pad full of wool evenly.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	And consider every hour of the night or day to ensure that the broken member's position is not altered nor the ligature loosened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	Therefore, rectify it all with your best efforts.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	And provide the patient's food according to the order we outlined earlier, so that their diet is soft at first until the jaw begins to tighten; then you must thicken their food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	For the jaw and leg are usually bound for forty days; it must then be loosened, a bath administered, and it is anointed with ointments that correct it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	But if the fracture is foul and crushed, then do not remove from it the ligature and splints for fifty days or up to two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	### On Restoring a Broken Arm.
Caput XIII.	Chapter 13.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	The arm is composed of two bones which are called the two forearm bones.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	One of these is small; this one follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	The other one is large and it is placed below the small bone from underneath.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	Perhaps only the larger forearm bone is broken, or perhaps it's just the smaller one; perhaps they are both broken at once.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	When the lower jaw is broken in a small area, its restoration is easy and healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	And when the lower jaw is broken badly, its fracture is bad, and healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	This situation is worse when both bones break at the same time.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	If the broken bone is a small part of the upper jaw, it is best for the doctor to apply a small extension during its restoration until they are level.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	If the broken bone is a large part of the jaw, then a very strong extension must be applied.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	A hand-shaped mould should be placed during its restoration with the extended part elevated on a pillow.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	The thumb of the hand should be higher than all its fingers and its knuckles lower than any other or the rest: the patient must then sit square on themselves with a pillow before them or directly under them at an elevated height so as not to cause them effort.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	Then the attendant should extend their arm from beneath it or with their hand or with a ligature.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	Another attendant must similarly extend from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	Then the doctor should level the bone until it is returned to its best possible form.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	But if there are splinters of bone in the fracture then try to restore every piece back into its place with your strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	If however you see a splinter that has separated and is piercing the skin, with no hope of restoring it, then find its place and remove it as we have said above.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	If there is a fracture with a wound, I have already made a special chapter on it, so take the treatment from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	If at the beginning of your restoration a hot abscess occurs, then line a piece of cloth with an ointment made of rose oil, white wax and beeswax of medium thickness and softness: bind the cloth on it tightly with fine bandages until the abscess subsides; then remove the ointment and apply a plaster prepared from flour and egg whites.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	Then apply splints; the one applied over the fracture itself should be somewhat wider and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	And note that the number of splints for the arm is six in most cases; whether there is a fracture in one bone or two bones at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then apply your bandage over the fracture site more tightly and strongly; somewhat tighter above or below it: or make the bandaging softer where indicated earlier in this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	And the cloths that wrap around the fracture should be soft and moist; not hard or rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	And the thread that binds it should be of pure linen, medium between fine and coarse, as we have said.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	And examine the limb and its ligaments after several days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	If anything that requires correction occurs, such as itching of the limb: then you should bathe the limb with warm water until the itching stops and release the limb from bandaging until it rests; after that repeat the binding.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	If the bandage is already loosened, and the bone removed along with similar things: then you must correct it all by your skill, and examine it again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	If nourishment is prevented from reaching the limb due to excessive constriction, then you must soften it a little and leave it for several days until nourishment can reach it again, then tighten it.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	If none of the aforementioned problems occur to the patient then they need not be released until after around twenty days.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	Then let the patient's hand hang from their neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	Their neck should be level [with the wound] and they must be prevented from any violent movements by their own strength.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	Make them sleep on their back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	This fracture heals within thirty days or thirty-two, perhaps twenty-eight.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	All of this depends on the characteristics of the individual's constitution and strength.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	On the healing of fractures to the hand.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 14.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	It is rare for the fingers or knuckles of the hand to suffer fracture.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	This does not occur unless by frequent attrition [of these bones].
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	When fracture or attrition of the heel occurs then the patient must be seated square [on an elevated seat] and a corresponding stool placed before them.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	Then place their hand upon it, outstretched.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	Then let the attendant stretch the broken bones until they join together with good alignment.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	Then it is necessary to apply a plaster and lint, lest a warm abscess occur.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	Next place the dressing on top according to the size of the wound, and you have now wrapped it with a linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	But if the fracture is towards the lower part near the sole of the foot, then make a similar sphere out of cloth and advise the patient to press their fractured foot against it; afterwards bind it with a long cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	And let the dressing be made of leather, which should be soft so that it conforms to the shape of the foot; and bind it as tightly as is required.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	But if the fracture is on the outside, then you must place a dressing on top and another underneath on the sole of the foot; and let the hand be open and straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	Next bind it as you would wrap the hand, and extend this binding between the toes with a bandage.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	If any of the joints are fractured, then if it is the thumb bind as required.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	Then bind it with the foot, and if there is swelling apply a straight dressing to it; this will raise the fracture and prevent movement.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	But if the fracture is in any other fingers such as the middle, index, little or ring finger; then bind it and secure it with a healthy finger next to it, or you may bind all of them together in sequence which is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	Or apply a small dressing on top as we said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	And be mindful of the restoration process and afterwards as you deal with any warm abscesses; apply what is necessary when something occurs according to your instructions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	The restoration of a broken hip.
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	The hip bone is frequently broken, and this becomes apparent to the senses: since it turns towards the inner and rear parts.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	And its restoration is done in such a way that the ligament above the fracture is tied tight, and another ligament beneath the fracture.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	And the patient shall be laid out on their face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	Then the attendant must stretch out every ligament to its proper place according to its equality: and this when there is a fracture in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	But if the fracture is near the root of the hip bone, then let a ligament be towards the pectineal muscle, so that the stretching goes upwards: and another ligament beneath the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	And similarly if the fracture is near the knee, then let a ligament be near the knee, so that the stretching goes downwards.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	Then the physician should equalize the bone with both hands until it is brought back to its normal shape; and the bone must be joined by a good joining together.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	Then it is necessary to put on a plaster cast and bandage if the limb does not develop an abscess.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	But if there is an abscess, then leave it for a few days until the hot abscess subsides; afterwards return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	The bandage should be like this:
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	You must wrap over the fracture a piece of linen cloth, that is, a bandage; and twice double it, or even triple it: and let there be some extra left over.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	Then wrap the leg until you reach the heel at the base of the buttocks.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	Insert a long thread between the hip and leg near the knee towards the bottom, and the ends of the thread come out from the upper part of both sides.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	Then wrap the remaining bandage over the leg and hip.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	Then place splints over the hip at the fracture site, and put one splint over the leg bone.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	Then fill the gaps between the leg and hip with soft pads to even out the tightness.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	Then start with a tight bandage from the middle, over the fracture site with three or four turns.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	And the further you extend the bandage from the fracture site, let your bandaging be looser and softer.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	Then go towards the two ends of the thread that you inserted between the hip and leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	Tie with both three splints which are above.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	Then go with the two ends of thread towards the bottom until you reach the heel of the foot.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	And with both, tighten the ends of the splints from the other side so that the bandage does not come off its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	Then leave the bandage on until it is healed so that no erosion, abscess or swelling happens to the limb and similar things.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	If any of these happen, then...
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	Soak it with the remedy for that problem, and correct what happened completely as we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	If there is a piece of bone that pierces from the bone itself: then it must be removed equally, if it is possible for you to do so.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	And if not, put it over that [piece of bone], remove it, and care for the one whose mention has preceded, until they are healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	And sometimes this fracture of the hip is tightened, besides what is added to it are splints, as we have said for the aid and arm.
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	However, with this fracture being restored in such a way as to not cause the infirm to limp.
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	And if it is restored solely, besides what is applied to its other leg, then it is necessary that the infirm will always limp.
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	And you should know that the hip is tightened within fifty days, or slightly more, or less: all of this depends on the diversity of complexions and other bodily dispositions.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	On restoring the fracture of the knee-cap.
Caput XVI.	Chapter 16.
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	Know that the knee-cap rarely fractures but often becomes worn down through attrition.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	If the knee-cap does fracture, then it will either be a crack or a hole in its parts.
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	And this occurs both with and without a wound.
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	And it stands over it all with feeling.
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	And its restoration is such that what has been torn apart from its parts will be levelled with the digits until it joins and knits together as far as possible in terms of evenness, ease, and knitting.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	Then apply a plaster made of sesame flour or wheat flour with egg white: place over it a round splint if needed: and secure this from above with a suitable bandage to hold it in place.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	Then consider all the arrangements we described for other fractures such as warm inflammation and similar conditions; apply to each whatever is appropriate until healing occurs.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	## On Restoration of a Broken Leg.
Caput XVII.	Chapter 17.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	You should be aware that the leg has two bones; one is thick and called the thigh bone, and the other is thin and known as the shinbone.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	Both types of leg bone can fracture in the same ways as the two bones of the arm; consequently, their restoration is equal and treatment is identical.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	If both leg bones break at the same time, the leg becomes completely dislocated.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	If the thin bone breaks, the leg turns towards the front.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	If the thick bone breaks you will find it below; and this is among those that are not concealed from view.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	Then apply traction, alignment, and splinting equally as for the arm.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	However, if the leg fracture is severe with many jagged edges, you must apply less traction and gentler alignment.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	The treatment of the leg differs from that of the arm in one respect; when you have aligned the splints and completed all other steps, take two wooden splints made from pine used for roofing tiles and crafted from palm leaves: choose those with medium thickness and not too thin; their length should match the distance from knee to foot.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	Then roll each cloth twice along its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	And place one part of the leg from one side, and the other from the other side; and let they be from the knee down to below the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	Then bind the two bandages in three places at both ends and in the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	For when restraint is prohibited, the leg deviates to the right and left, and stands in a good position.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	And now let there be administered a splint of wood according to the length of the leg, and place the leg upon it so as to preserve it from movement.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	And indeed you should most definitely do this for a fracture when there is an accompanying wound.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	Then examine the leg every day, and be attentive to it with the utmost care from abscesses, or swelling, or other things.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	If therefore anything of these happens, then oppose it with that which is necessary until it be cured, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	On the fracture of the bones of the foot and toes.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter 18.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	Indeed, the calcaneus does not completely fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	The bones of the foot sometimes fracture, as do the toes; and they only break in multiple places due to abrasion.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	If the bones of the foot fracture and you see those bones rising above one another, then let the patient put their foot upon prepared ground as if they are walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	Stand thou then, and place thy foot over that which is elevated from those bones; afterwards press, or trample it down; and make it even until it returns to its proper place.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	Then apply the plaster and put some tow on top; place under the belly of the foot a small board with two flat ends.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	Then bind it with a bandage suitable for the foot, after you have wrapped it up with linen and other things that are required.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	When therefore three or four days have passed, then untie the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	For you will find that the bones have become even if they were broken or displaced.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	The operation for them is therefore as you see it to be.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	But if any of the toes are broken, restore them and make them even according to what I have explained to you concerning the restoration of the fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	Then place a splint under the toe according to its length and make it slightly wider; then put beneath the foot this board which I have explained to you, and bind it with a suitable bandage.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	But if what is broken of the bones is two or three or more, then place a splint over the whole toe of its appropriate size wrapped in linen cloth; bind this board at the lower part of the foot; and let it stand on one end of the board outside the belly of the foot so that it may hold by good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	And it is fitting for you to remember all that I have said concerning other fractures from the accidents which we have discussed; apply everything appropriate to each accident.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	On the fracture of a woman's pubic bone, the peg-like bone, and the man's thighbone.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	When a woman's pubic bone is fractured, make her sit on a square-shaped seat.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	Then lean her slightly towards the back of her body and have someone hold her from behind.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	Then the midwife should fill her pubic region with cotton wool until it is full and a sphere-like shape is formed from the pubic bone.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	Then shake the woman gently and slowly raise her back up.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	For that cotton wool will exit until it is like a sphere before the pubic bone's opening, and the broken bone returns to its place.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	Then place a small cushion under her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	So when she wants to urinate again, gently remove the cotton wool and let her urinate; then return it as you first put it in; afterwards, have her go back to her cushion.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	Have her do this for seven days or so until the bone is restored.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	And if you wish, take a lizard's gallbladder and bind it with a reed tube over the opening, then insert the entire gallbladder into her pubic region.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	Then blow into the tube with might until the gallbladder is inflated within her pubic region as the fracture returns.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	Then it should be filled with cotton as we described, for several days until she is healed.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	When the bone of the pecten in a man or woman breaks, then treat it with the same procedure and apparatus that we described for repairing the ankle bone.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	The correct procedure is not hidden from those close fractures which rarely occur, especially to one who has some expertise or practice.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	And understand my book well, because this very fracture itself will indicate to you the correct procedure for setting and splinting it in many cases; so do understand it.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	When the male penis is broken, take the throat of a goose; insert this rod into it.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	Then place over it a bandage made of cloth and wrap the area up; keep this on for three days or thereabouts, and if God wills, healing will occur.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	On repairing fractures with accompanying wounds.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	If a fracture occurs along with an open wound, especially if it is large, such as the bone of the hip or thigh or similar, you should bleed the patient without delay; if the indications for bleeding are present, proceed according to what has been mentioned before.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	If the wound is discharging blood, you must proceed promptly to cut away its edges; sprinkle over this some ground zege (Cyperus rotundas) powder if no other medication is immediately available.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	Then begin to treat the fracture on that very day; do not postpone this unless an abscess occurs later on.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	If an abscess of the hot type occurs, then delay treating the fracture until the ninth day, so that the abscess may subside.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	And do not approach him on the third day or the fourth at all, for you would cause bad things to happen to him.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	If the broken bone is prominent under the skin, you should attempt to realign it and make it even with your hands gently and with little force.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	If its extension is not prepared and you cannot realign it with your hands, then reduce it with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And this is an instrument that is made of iron, its length being the quantity of seven or eight fingers, and its width according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	And for this reason it is necessary that the physician take three or four of them according to how much he needs for its treatment in every kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	And it should be round, with a small thickness so that it is not doubled when compressed on top of it during the procedure, and have sharp edges with a bevel at its ends.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	And its upper part should be rounded to thickness from the middle of it down to its lower ends.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	In this operation, the physician must place its sharp curved end over the protruding bone and push it with one movement until the broken ends are brought together in alignment.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	Try to bring the ends of the fracture into alignment with each other.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	If the end of its broken bone is thin and does not take the instrument well, then it is necessary to cut off the end of that bone until the instrument can get a good purchase on it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	If you cannot reduce it with what we have described, then cut it with what is appropriate for it from the incisions we mentioned; or saw it with one of the saws in whatever way possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	Then scrape off what remains on the bone of roughness and small splinters.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	So when the bone is reduced and the patient experiences severe pain after its reduction, then you know that it has not returned to its natural position.
Fac ergo illud.	Do so.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	For you cause the patient great discomfort when your restoration of the bone is complete.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	Then immerse a cloth in black astringent wine.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	And especially if it is summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	And do not apply poultices, nor anything with oil; so as to not cause the wound to become gangrenous and corrupt.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	Then administer pills at the hour of your completion of the bone restoration.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	And leave the wound open; such that you cut a hole with scissors into the bandages according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	And be careful not to bind the wound tightly over the fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	For many times have stupid doctors done this; and they caused the death of their patients, or gangrene, or pus, that is, suppuration.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	And your binding should be soft, gentle; different from the bindings of other fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	If the wound is serious or extensive and you fear some of the complications we have described and find that there is pain at a particular spot, then it should not be necessary to apply stars over it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	And make rolls from hard linen cloths instead of the stars and compress it with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	However when it is after one day or two and you see the wound begin to produce pus then remove from above it the linen cloth which you placed over it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	Then apply dressings and ointments with which we are accustomed to treat wounds like the four-ingredient ointment and those similar to it.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	And it is advisable that you loosen any binding.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	And examine the wound every day morning and evening until it is healed.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	And the limb should be prepared so that pus runs freely from it downwards.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	If much time passes since the injury was sustained and it does not heal or cease producing pus then you should know that there are small splinters of bone within it.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	For this reason one must probe the wound with a probe.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	How many of these small splinters have become detached you must remove them and extract those still within the wound.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	And of those that are not detached and pierce the flesh causing pain one should attempt to cut them so they may be removed by any means possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	If a proud flesh or spreading abscess arises from the wound that is, an inflammatory swelling of various kinds or another type of corruption and putrefaction then one must apply to each accordingly with what has already been described in their respective chapters.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	And from that which is necessary for my speech to stand on, and to whom you make your present mind when a bone is broken, and it protrudes above the member, like the hip bone, and the assistor, and similar to these of the large members, there is, so as not to presume its traction, for many times death occurs from it; indeed, leave it alone until it rots.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	Perhaps indeed it will fall by itself after twenty days, or thirty.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	Then therefore treat the wound if it seems to you; and if not, leave it be.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	On treating skin nodules on a fracture site.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	Many times, this nodule occurs on the site of healing from fracture.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	Especially when it is near joints; and the shape of the member is affected by it.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	And perhaps prevents the limb from its natural function.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	Therefore consider it then, if the nodule is fresh; apply to it medicines which have astringent properties, such as aloe, frankincense, myrrh, resin, gum arabic, and similar.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	Such that you take from these some or all of them; mix them with astringent wine, or with egg white, or with vinegar; and place this mixture on the nodule, wrapped in lint, and bind it tightly.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	And leave the binding, do not remove it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	Then dissolve that binding, and apply another, until the nodule is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	Either tightly bind over the same sheet of lead, off-centre.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	For lead is the property of removing all that is feared from the members.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	But if the stitch has already turned into a stone and it is tight, and necessity urgently requires its removal: then find it on top of it from its upper side, and cut off the protruding superfluity; or scrape it with some scrapers until it is removed: and take care of that place until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	On the treatment when restored, and the member remains thin after that, not according to its nature.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	When the fracture of bone is restored, and the member remains thin after that, weak: then it is not so but for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	One of which is the abundance of loosening and binding the bandage not as it should be: either due to an excess of tightness of the bindings until nourishment is prevented from reaching the member; or due to an abundance of superfluous ointment at the wrong time; or due to a lack of blood in the body of the patient, and their weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	And its treatment is to feed the patient, and make their body soft until blood multiplies in them.
Et administra balneum.	And provide a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	And introduce joy and happiness over them.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	Then put tar on the member: so that it draws the poison to itself greatly.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	And treat it with frequent ointment of warm water until nourishment runs through, and returns to its natural form.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	The treatment of fractured bones when they are restored crookedly.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter 23.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	When it happens that a limb has already been restored after its healing in a crooked manner, and there is an elevation of the broken bone, or knottedness: and it is marred by this defect in the shape of the limb, nevertheless the limb is not hindered from its natural operation: then you should not heed the counsel of him who thinks that the limb ought to be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	And there have been many foolish physicians and restorers who did that in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	And this operation is truly blameworthy, leading to death or great fear, so that it might be mortal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	But if the lameness and knottedness are recent: then it is necessary that [the limb] be embrocated with warm water, in which softening herbs have been boiled, such as althea leaves and its root, and conyfy, and similar things.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	And make for him a plaster with a softening plaster, such as properly made dichile.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	Or take the mucilage of althea root, and mix it with goose fat or sesame oil: and plaster [the limb] with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	Or take fat figs, and pound them with pigeon dung, and similar things which are called by the name of medicines that reduce solidity.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	And sometimes knottedness is resolved by frequent, old, and gentle friction which is done with moist hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	And the movement of the limb should be applied to every part at all hours.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	If the curvature has already progressed and become severe, and it has turned into a bone spur, and the need for treatment with iron has arisen, then one must cut its upper part, release the bone continuity, and incise what is excessive due to nodulation or bone with delicate cutters; and care should be taken in that with diligence and effort.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	About the discussion on dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	Dislocation is the displacement of certain joints from their proper place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	Why it is forbidden to move [it] itself, and the shape of the limb is distorted.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	And it causes severe pains and injuries to happen in the afflicted person.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	When dislocation happens to someone, then one must hasten to restore it; and not delay [it] at all.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	For if one delays [treatment], the site becomes inflamed, and perhaps with that reduction of the dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	Because of that, it is not advisable to move [it] or stretch during the hour of its inflammation.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	Since it often causes spasms and painful injuries to happen.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	But when that happens, then one must hurry to the bloodletting of the patient.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	Then leave [it] alone until the inflammation quiets down.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	After that, the limb should be anointed with warm water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	Then it should be pulled out gently.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And every part that comes to mind must be treated with respect.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	I have already arranged the headings of dislocations, as well as what preceded it with regards to fractures, from top to bottom of the body.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	On treating the dislocation of the lower jaw.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25.
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	Both jaws rarely become dislocated unless it's just one of them.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	And the only way both jaws can become dislocated is through one of two methods.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	Or they may be slightly removed from their places by slight movement, and somewhat softened in the process.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	Or they may become fully dislocated until the jaws soften at the level of the chest, and so much saliva runs out that he cannot hold it back, nor can close his mouth, and his tongue is rolled up with speech.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	But when the dislocation is slight, it returns to its place of its own accord after a short while.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	If it is a complete dislocation however, then its reduction must be administered quickly and not delayed at all: the assistant should hold the patient's head, while the surgeon inserts his thumb of one hand into the root of the dislocated jaw between their teeth if only one jaw has become dislocated.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	Or they may insert both thumbs together if the jaws have become dislocated on both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	And his remaining fingers should stay outside of the patient's mouth with which he holds it steady.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	And instruct the patient to clean their jaws and move them around for chewing on all sides.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	And the physician should move the jaw to one side, and push it until it returns to its place.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	If its return is difficult, especially if both jaws are affected at the same time: then apply steam with warm water and oil until it becomes easy to move them both; do not delay reducing movement of either side at all, as we have said.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	When they return and are level with each other, and the patient's mouth is closed without any slackness: then place over them small pieces of cloth that have been coated in wax; and rose-scented oil.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	Afterwards, bind it with soft bandages without difficulty.
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	And the patient should sleep on their back; and place his head resting between two pillows so that he cannot move it from side to side; nor shall he attempt or be forced to chew anything; rather let him take his food by gentle suction until such time as his pains are removed, and his jaw loosened: then may he eat what he wishes and give it without difficulty.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	He should not exert himself in the use of his mouth for eating, drinking, or yawning until such time as the jaw is loosened and healed.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	But if the return of both jaws is difficult when they are dislocated at any time and do not return to their places; then often there result from this fevers with constant sweating: and perhaps the patient's stomach is loosened, and perhaps he vomits pure bile.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	Therefore when you see this, then know that it is a grave matter; and often the patient whose jaws are so dislocated dies within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	On reducing the dislocation of the Fork bone and upper arm.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	The Fork bone does not become dislocated from the inner side because of its continuity with the chest.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	It becomes dislocated sometimes outwards, which is clear to sense perception.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	And its restoration is for the sick person to lie on their back and stretch out their arms.
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	Then squeeze the area with your palm using firm pressure because it will go back into place.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	Then apply an ointment and compresses to it and bind it tightly.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	The extremities that follow the elbow and are continuous with it do not become dislocated except rarely.
Quod si dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	But if it does become dislocated some day, then it must be restored and adjusted according to what we have said and prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	Then put an ointment and compresses on it and bandage it tightly.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	And instruct the sick person to remain calm and at rest until they have healed.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	And with this same treatment the upper arm is restored when it too becomes separated from its place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	On reducing the dislocation of the upper arm.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	Know that the upper arm does not become dislocated except in three ways.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	One of which is to dislocate toward the side of the little rib below.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	The second is to dislocate towards the side of the chest.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	And perhaps it is dislocated in the upper part of the arm, which occurs rarely.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	It does not become dislocated at the back because of the blade bone (scapula).
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	And it is not dislocated to the front due to nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	Indeed it is most often dislocated and comes out towards the lower little rib, especially among those whose flesh is scant.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	Since it goes out quickly in them, and comes back in quickly.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	But in those whose flesh is abundant, it is the opposite of that; namely, that it goes out with difficulty and comes back in with difficulty.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	And perhaps it happens to some men that there is a blow or fall and the arm becomes dislocated with a hot swelling, and because of this they think it has already been dislocated.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	Therefore it is necessary that you examine it until you stand firm about its certainty, and then proceed with the cure of it.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	A dislocation is recognized when it is towards the lower little rib; and you must distinguish between a dislocated arm and a healthy one.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	For you find between them an evident difference and find in the head of the dislocated arm a hollow, and below the little rib near the touch of the head of the arm as if it were an egg; and the sufferer cannot draw his hand to his ear nor move it with all motions.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	Similarly, if it is dislocated towards the chest or upwards, you will find a clear swelling that cannot be hidden.
